As most people seem to drive through YNP and only jump out to take photos to say they have “seen” YNP, I cannot stress enough to visit this location early in the day or late afternoon to avoid all the annoying tourists.
This is a must do. Very beautiful and a lot to see. We spent a lot of time at this location and it was well worth the time we spent.
Hiking, waterfalls, & bison, oh my! A trip to Yellowstone needs to include a day at the canyon. We even had a visit from a rather large bison who just parked himself 5 feet from the parking lot.
another one of the "must see" stops along the grand loop. Fantastic views from several vantage points.

This is a beautiful place to visit and you need to bring a camera you will want to take a ton. It’s an easy walk and well worth the time to stop and visit I would not miss this if you are in Yellowstone!

Worth the trip. It takes an hour or so to reach from Tower-Roosevelt because the road is winding and the speed limit generally 35 MPH. We didn’t see any wildlife on the road there, but we already had our fill in the Lamar Valley. We reached Canyon Village and then passed the entrance to the North Rim drive (which was jammed with cars) and kept going a few miles to the South Rim drive. At the end of the road is a lookout called Artist Point. Less cars and a large parking lot so it was easier to reach. There were probably 150 people at the lookout and the views were spectacular. It was definitely worth the drive.
We went on a Yellowstone in a Day Tour. Great tour, even though it was very long. You saw everything. The canyon is not to be missed.
Truly a wonder to behold! Absolutely gorgeous! Take time to explore and appreciate! This entire trip was filled with beauty and this spot was one of the top!
Jaw dropping views! The viewpoints have names like Artists Point and Inspiration Point for a reason. Some of the most amazing sights in the park. Puts the "Yellow" in Yellowstone.
Beautiful part of the park. The trail can be a challenge. But the views are awesome. Be sure to include this stop.

If you go to Yellowstone and miss seeing the canyon ( I doubt anyone really has ) you’ve missed an amazing sight.
Easily viewed from overlooks so it doesn’t need to be a big time killer but in the other hand you could easily spend as much time taking in the view from multiple locations ( but they all start to look the same after awhile.
Lower falls is more spectacular than upper when viewed from the south rim. Looked like a new upper falls observation point on north rim but closed when we visited

The canyon is beautiful, from the falls to further on, it is an impressive sight. Interesting rock formations, varied colors, the sound of water rushing down the canyon and all still natural - no one can raft down the canyon.

places_url_reviews_title: One of the best scenic spots
places_url_reviews_comment: This one of the "must see" spots if you're visiting or just having to drive through. It's gorgeous, the parking lot is close to the lookout, and it's amazing and almost always clear.

places_url_reviews_title: Beautiful Canyon with Beautiful Water Falls
places_url_reviews_comment: One of the best parts of Yellowstone for me was the Grand Canyon of Yellowstone, along with the Beautiful Upper Water Fall and the Lower Falls. Even though the canyon is not as big as the Grand Canyon in Arizona, it is a beautiful canyon and a beautiful area. Many spots to view the Canyon, each was a time to take more photo's. Highly recommended.

places_url_reviews_title: Great views - go early or late in the day for parking
places_url_reviews_comment: This is a must see. We did the Brink of the Upper Falls, Artist's Point (amazing and you can walk from here to Sublime Point), Red Rock Point (highly recommended) and Lookout Point. All were wonderful and give different perspectives of the area. We went late afternoon/early evening and the parking was easing up a bit then.
I couldn't believe the natural beauty in this place and thought of God's creation "How Great Thou Art". Absolutely stunning. The rock formations, waterfalls just Awesome.

Definitely a beautiful are with some incredible views. it wasn't my favorite part of Yellowstone and it was maybe a little underwhelming after I had recently seen the Grand Canyon again, but still well worth a visit.

places_url_reviews_title: Very nice but get there early
places_url_reviews_comment: Beautiful place in a beautiful place but get there early as parking was very hard at certain times of the day. Gets very crowded.
The Grand Canyon and Yellowstone Falls are THE iconic photo of the park! We visited multiple times. Shortly after sunrise, my daughter caught a photo with the falls descending into a rainbow.

places_url_reviews_title: Beautiful, take it in from both sides
places_url_reviews_comment: This is one of the main reasons to see Yellowstone (geysers and wildlife are the others). We drove the south Rim first and than the north rim. Best photo op is at Artists Point on the south rim. The traffic gets bad at times in the south rim. You could park at the Canyon Lodge lots and walk over to save the time.
Incredibly beautiful! Certainly make the trip to see the Upper and Lower views. Make the hike to the waterfall.

Even though this was the most crowded hike we did, it was spectacular! We went in early August and it was hot. If you take it to the bottom, be prepared for the steep uphill climb. I’m in great physical shape but was panting on the uphill because of the altitude. Definitely not recommended for small children or elderly folks we saw too many small children crying and parents who had to make the climb carrying children...in 90 degree heat. In my opinion, children under 8 won’t be able to appreciate it anyway so just stay at the top and have an enjoyable day. For everyone else, the strenuous climb is well worth it. There are viewing outlooks in several places that make for great pictures, but you must wait your turn because of the crowds. As long as you aren’t in a hurry, it is an amazing sight to see.

The Grand canyon of Yellowstone should not be missed. There are plenty of simple view point hikes and longer hikes depending on your physical fitness. It can be very warm so make sure that you have plenty of water with you. The views are beautiful and seem better at every site. Another way to see the canyon is on horseback. There is a stable nearby. The day we visited the canyon our visit was interrupted by a thunder and lightning storm that made us seek shelter in one of the Park resturants. The main hike of hundreds of steps into the canyon that my son wanted to take was closed because of construction. A lot of construction is going on throughout the park in the summer so you never know what will be available.
Beautiful place to visit. We were not able to do the lower falls and were bummed but the view from the upper falls was amazing.

places_url_reviews_title: Breathtaking views of God's green earth!
places_url_reviews_comment: This is a must see when you are in the park. The hike down to the lower falls is a little long but the view and the roar of the falls is magnificent as you look out over the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone.

Any path, rim, or view you take of this canyon is breathtaking. Artist point is a highlight of course. An easy to moderate short hike with spectacular view is the hike from Artist point to Sublime point- fantastic.
We were in Yellowstone and stopped to see this. Easy to get to and easy walking to see. Very beautiful scenery. Obviously not as big AS the Grand Canyon, but still breathtaking
We drove through both north and south rims of the canyon and hiked out to each of the overlooks. Truly spectacular.

The views from the overlook here are stunning. It is a short walk from the far end of the parking lot to the observation points, and it is absolutely worth it. Even though the crowds were large, we were able to enjoy the overlook and get some great photos with a little patience.
This was simply put, spectacular! I had not researched Yellowstone enough to realize this particular feature existed, and really appreciated the surprise. It was breathtaking.
Lots of trails closed around the Grand Canyon when we visited but still able to do a few hikes in the are.

really amazing place. Go early because parking problem/ Usually after 9:30-10:00 a.m. they are full. Take a view from Artistic point. Take a trek- it worth. Take a stroll on South and North rim- all you can do in the full day

We rode into the grand canyon of the Yellowstone on our motorcycles, and had an enjoyable time. It was a beautiful area, and the trails are well marked. There was a park employee there who had a spotting scope on an osprey nest, and was letting everyone look through it.
Breath taking beautiful!! Sit awhile and take it all in. Too many folk rushing to get the picture or selfie. Just relax and enjoy.

This steep dirt hiking trail is a challenge with a tremendous view! Keep your kids close as there are no guard rails on most of the trail. BUT this is a truly amazing view of the falls and the canyon. If you don't want to hike so much (its not really that hard) just go past the first trail head and take the second trail to an overlook.
This is why you come to Yellowstone. So amazing, stunning, and huge! Many places to stop. Both hard and easy hikes.

The falls are stunning, both upper, lower and everywhere in between. If you're in a car you'll need to park in one of the designated areas, which can get busy but people are leaving all the time so be patient; it’s worth the wait.
The views are amazing and do take time to walk the extra mile or so away from the crowds. More than once we couldn’t see anyone else but could always hear the roar of the magnificent river.
If you are in the park you must visit the Grand Canyon of Yellowstone. The vistas are spectacular. Unfortunately, at peak season you enjoy these visits with 10000 other people.

Gorgeous - did one side in the afternoon sun (beautiful colors in the canyon), and the other side at sunrise, from Artist point. Beautiful from both sides, and amazing to think this canyon was carved in a matter of hours/days in a flash flood!

places_url_reviews_title: We Had a Great Time in Yellowstone!
places_url_reviews_comment: My husband and I just returned from Yellowstone and the Grand Tetons. What a wonderful adventure! The first day we drove in from Cody, Wyoming, toured part of the park and then stayed the next three nights in West Yellowstone. The first day in the park we had our maps and we were getting lost. That night I thought there should be a better way to see Yellowstone. I found a GyPSy guide app and installed it on my phone. It needs to downloaded BEFORE you go to the park. This app was wonderful! It was like having our own tour guide. This app made a HUGE difference in our trip. The app is only $9.99 for Yellowstone and Grand Tetons. We found our trip to be much more relaxing and educational. We visited Yellowstone Grand Canyon the first day and could not find a parking space. One of the parking lots was closed down. The front clerk at the hotel told us to leave for the park before 6:30 and we will get through before the crowd. What a difference it made for us! We went to Yellowstone Grand Canyon and had no crowds. We took a trail down close to the bottom. It is so beautiful!

The views take your breath away from every direction. Trails are clearly marked and there are many to choose from. If you are extra brave or not so smart, you can even walk out onto ledges in certain areas. Wish we had more time. Will definitely be back.

It gets crowded but for good reason...this is one of the most beautiful places in the world, with sweeping vistas and amazing views all around. Arrive early or late to avoid the crowds, and hiking along the north or south rim is a nice way to see it without as many people around.
This is a must see stop in Yellowstone. Go early because the parking lot was very busy mid morning. You will not reget the stop!

First I would plan on getting to artist view and brink of lower falls by 9am at latest. We arrived at artist view at 8:30 and parking was filling up and followed with the brink which was almost full. (Early evening probably good too) it is definitely worth it. While the thermal areas of the park get a lot of press, this area is every bit as inspiring. Even with the challenge of construction, you can still get great views and of course there is the option of hiking in the canyon area. Definitely don’t miss stopping here!

places_url_reviews_title: Grand View Overlook has a great view
places_url_reviews_comment: Spend some time looking out over the Grand View Overlook as it shows a 180 degree view of the canyon. It is a gorgeous place that has a river running at the bottom of it.

We took several hikes in the canyon from the north rim to the south rim. My personal favorite was going down 600 ft to the top of the upper falls and peer down the whole canyon. It made the hike back up worth it!

places_url_reviews_title: Go early or late - amazing views
places_url_reviews_comment: Two popular trails are closed now - uncle Toms and inspiration point. So it’s forcing more crowds in less locations. We went to artist point around 7:30pm - easy parking and only a few people there. We also stopped at the view of upper falls. We did the brink of lower falls at 7:30am. Had it to ourselves. Not to be missed - amazing view next to the falls. You will have a hard time parking during the day. I recommend hiking during the later morning or early afternoon.
Visit Artists View earlier in the day for best time to take photos of Lower Falls from across the canyon. The brink of Lower Falls is a fascinating way to see the Falls from above.
One of the must see sights in Yellowstone. Be sure to visit both the upper and lower falls. The walks are not far, and well worth it.
First stop in our visit to Yellowstone and it was absolutely stunning. Be sure to come as early as possible and visit some viewpoints and do some trails.
Beautiful view from the top of the falls. Rainbows are constant. You do earn it by the trek back up the switchbacks.

Sometimes you see images in a book or on the internet, and think: I would like to see this. It may a disappointment, a 'this is what I expected' or a WOW experience when you do see it. This one is for sure a WOW!
To start with a less positive thing: you need to drive a long time (we entered via the West entrance) to get here. If there are queues on the road (in case animals walk close to or on the road), you easily need 1:30-2:00 to get here. The views are very impressive, viewpoints can be reached by car, often combined with short trails (typically < 0.5 mile)
I read in some comments a comparison with the Grand Canyon. It is a totally different type of canyon, the advantage of this one is that it is smaller and you can have a better total picture and can see the river and waterfalls.
Apart from the awesome views, you can also walk to the upper and lower falls. A lot of trails were closed at the lower falls though since they were rebuilding some sections. Good they do this, but unfortunate if you intended to hike in that area.
Apart from the viewpoints where you can see a big section of the canyon, I like the fact that you can walk till the section where the water dives of the upper falls.
Truly spectacular scenery. Mother nature has created a breathtaking place for nature to be preserved and appreciated.
This is absolutely stunning! Best place to view is at the Artist Point. The waterfall and white water at the bottom of the very deep canyon will take your breath away.
Expect a long wait in your vehicle, as there is limited parking with a one way in/ one way out access... but it is worth it! Awful pit bathrooms there so try to go before you go 💩🤪
We stayed at Canyon Lodge so we could visit when it was not crowded. It is worth visiting at different times of the day. There are accessible overlooks for everyone to get a nice view.
The canyon area is super beautiful. There is a great overlook, but it is filled with people. Go on a hike on one of the nearby trails. You'll be away from people and get some great views.

Oh wao. Not to be missed. There is a nice hike that starts from the parking lot. By nice, it takes 2 hrs (there and 2hrs back) and follows the canyon to the "end". Sublime point itself isn't worth it, but the journey there is.
The canyon is magnificient. Colors, depth, views, vegetation, desert, rocks, trees... everything. Pictures don't do it justice.

places_url_reviews_title: Absolutely Gorgeous! Don't miss this area
places_url_reviews_comment: This is not always what those who are first-time visitors think of when thinking of Yellowstone. That said, it is breathtaking and should not be missed. There are drives along the north and south rim, but I highly recommend getting out and doing some of the trails for the best views. The hikes to the top of the falls lead to great views (the lower falls hike especially is strenuous and I wouldn't recommend it for those with health issues). When we went in July 2018 the Uncle Tom trail was closed and did not look like it would re-open in the near future.

Holy wow! Who knew this existed! It truly is a site to see. From the falls to the massive drop in the canyon. When it got there we had some scattered showers. As I got up to the overlook for pictures it started to rain /snow it was amazing! This place is a must see!
Most people think of the hot springs and geysers at Yellowstone but the Grand Canyon is a must see! All parts are awe inspiring. Take your time. Early morning is a wonderful time to visit.
Beautiful, big and powerful scenery. Recommend one of the walks past point Sublime and also the walk to the lakes. Got lost a bit but part of the fun.
What can you say about such a natural wonder? It is amazing and gorgeous. It is easy to access with a short walk from parking at the lower falls.
Breathtaking views, but walkways and parking super congested. Go before 10 or after 6 for less people traffic.
I would definitely check this out if you are in the Yellowstone area. You can take a 15 minute hike down to the river after you watch the waterfall from the top.

Definitely take the time to drive both rim drives and hike the trails on each one. The view are fantastic! On one of the trails you can get right on top of one of the falls without much effort. All of the trails are paved and easily walked by all.
Fabulous. Great view from the upper falls and a 600 foot down and 600 foot back up hike to the lower falls. Will see a rainbow at the lower falls
Breathtaking views. Makes you realize how much more there is to the world than your surroundings. Wonderful vacation

The classic view from Artist's Point was especially beautiful and we wished that the viewpoints that were closed had been open. Stopping at the brink of upper falls was an exhilarating experience not to be missed. The rest of our party hiked down to the brink of lower falls and thought it was beautiful while I enjoyed seeing it from several viewpoints near the parking area. Plan on spending a significant amount of time in this area of the park.

This is another awesome place to visit. The views are breathtaking. You can get plenty of awesome pictures of the scenery and landscape here. Plenty of signs to explain what you are looking at. Make sure you plan a stop here

One of the best things to see in the park! Start at Artists Point. Unfortunately, Inspiration Point, Uncle Tom’s Trail, and the North Rim trails all are closed for the year due to construction. BUT we did a fabulous hike to Sublime Point (same parking lot as Artists Point) which was not very crowded and had beautiful (if close to the edge) views. We also did a back country hike from a fork in the same trail to Ribbon Lake - end was a little anti climatic and trail was buggy. You can skip those two miles but do the one miler (round trip) to Sublime Point for sure. Get there early because this lot is a traffic jam in the summer by 10am, or after 5.

places_url_reviews_title: Many trails closed and just not as impressive as I remember
places_url_reviews_comment: Maybe I was in a bad mood because this was supposed to be a highlight of our trip and almost all of the trails were closed, but I just found this to be ok. It was so packed and the trees obscured part of the view. We made it to Artist Point and Brink of Lower and Upper falls. Those trails are steep and not well maintained, so I understand why renovation is necessary. Even my kids said, "We could have seen this through VR." Hopefully I can go back some day and see the parts I missed.

places_url_reviews_title: So many different ways to view it, all beautiful
places_url_reviews_comment: I went in July and thought the crowds would be unbearable. Yes artist point was crazy crowded even at 10:00 AM, but hike just a tenth of a mile past there and you’ll lose almost everyone. We hiked to inspiration point and saw maybe 20 people. Hike on the other side of the canyon near Lamar valley (Yellowstone river trail) and we were alone for hours. There are ways to find solace in this park, if you’re willing to put in some effort :) The canyon is beautiful and worth seeing from all angles.

I've included the falls in this review. I think this area is second only to the geysers in Yellowstone. It's a don't miss. Because of the name one's tempted to compare it with The Grand Canyon in Arizona-- they are similar only in that they are both canyons with a river. The falls are high and you can get very close. There's an area that you can descend steep stairs to the river. Even if you are in good shape remember you're at 8000' and it may be a struggle. But if you can make it without a lot of pain it's definitely spectacular.
Yes it was cool, yes you should see it. No it is not grand canyon worthy. Comparing it with that just brings dissapointment as its not all that.

Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone is breathtaking. I really didn't expect to much since I have been to the Grand Canyon and I was very pleasantly surprised. We ended up spending much of the day here just sitting and looking. From the waterfall to all of the canyon formations it is awesome to see. We looked at all of the pictures we took and they do not begin to do the place justice. You will not be disappointed.
you truly have to see this place to believe it! There are so many spots to just sit and gaze and be amazed at the beauty of this country!

places_url_reviews_title: Pit stops at view points or spend a day.
places_url_reviews_comment: If you’re pushed for time you can drive to all the view points for photo opportunities, Artist’s Point, brink of upper falls & lower falls etc or to fully explore there are rim walks, the hike down to the brink of Lower Falls & side trails. We’ve been to Yellowstone twice now for over a week each visit & still not managed to do it all. The Canyon is 1 of the must see’s if you’re only visiting for a short time & it’s very close to Canyon Village which is a good stop for toilets, drinks, lunch, gift shops & bear spray rentals.
Loved every minute of our Yellowstone trip. Grand Canyon of Yellowstone is fantastic. Leave several days to hit all of the amazing parts of Yellowstone

Yellowstone was never on my bucket list...but I am so glad I was able to go! I am a water person so all the lakes/cascades/falls etc...just BEAUTIFUL! If you have the opportunity to visit the Park GO! It is well worth the hikes/drive/time to see this beautiful place. We stayed in the park for 10 hours and it wasn't long enough...plan a few days to see everything...your ticket is good for 7 days.

Wow! That pretty much sums it up the first time you lay eyes on the falls from the excellent viewing point. Just an amazing sight. I’ve see the Grand Canyon (in Arizona) and this view tops it. Won’t go so far as saying the canyon is better, but the view of the falls and the beautiful green water rushing down the canyon with those wonderfully colored walls (reddish brown) is just an incredible sight. Wow!
Don't forget to do the little (but steep) trail to the lower falls and other outlook. Always breathtaking!

places_url_reviews_title: A highlight of Yellowstone National Park.
places_url_reviews_comment: The artist of Artist's Point was Thomas Moran, who came as official artist with the US government's Hayden survey party. His 1872 painting of The Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone helped persuade Congress to declare the country's (and the world's) first national park. See the Moran painting at the Smithsonian American Art Museum in Washington, DC. See its inspiration here, a short walk from the parking lot.
Best viewed by Artist Point...simply stunning both morning and evening. We went twice a day for three days.

places_url_reviews_title: Not necessarily for those afraid of heights
places_url_reviews_comment: The one hike down to the falls drops 600 feet and is steep with no hand rails. Definitely not for those afraid of heights.

Best advice is to get up early and drive directly to the Grand Canyon. We chose the North Rim Drive and stopped at the Lookout Point and Grand View. Get there ahead of the crowds and enjoy the beauty. The waterfall is incredible. If you're feeling energetic, do the hike down at Lookout Point. It's a steep climb, but well worth it. There is no hike at the Grand View stop, but incredible scenery everywhere you look. Leaving the parking lot at the Grand View stop, we saw a mama bear and her cubs. That caused a bear jam out of the lot! There are bathrooms at the Lookout Point lot.

Having previously visited the aptly named 'Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone' it was a pleasure to gaze upon this gorgeous spectacle again. The rock formations, the colours, the scale and of course the thundering roar of the water combines to create such a beautiful natural wonder. If you've never visited this area before, then I urge you to move it up your bucket list and go. This area will leave you speechless.

We stopped here on our drive around YNP and were glad we did. The colors of the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone are just spectacular. The only real downside is that the colors of the canyon don't translate to photos. You really just have to take it all in when you're there and commit to memory. We got lucky and went at a time when there were not scores of people milling about, but the area can definitely become crowded quickly! this is a MUST SEE, so be sure to add it to any trip you've planned to YNP.

places_url_reviews_title: A must see for anyone going to YNP
places_url_reviews_comment:
Although I have been to YNP hundreds of times, this remains one of the highlights of my trips. The scenery is spectacular and the beauty and majesty of the waterfall and the river down below make this one of the "must see" places in the park. There are several trails that you can go on for different places along the rim of the canyon. Uncle Tom's Trail is currently closed because they are totally remodeling that area, but there is Inspiration point, and Artist's point that can give you some spectacular views.
If you want to be there at the best times, go early in the morning before the tour buses and most of the people crowd up the area, or in the early evening when it gets a bit cooler.
There can be deerflies/horseflies and mosquitoes so be sure to take some insect repellent to keep them at bay. It can be very hot and sunny so be sure to wear sunscreen and appropriate head covering.

We really enjoyed all parts of the Yellowstone Grand Canyon. We drove the roads on the South and North Rims and also went to the Brink of the Falls. All were great. The views are forever and the falls are powerful. A MUST SEE!

We were very excited to see the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone, but almost every trail we tried was closed. We were able to see from one lookout on the south rim (all hikes closed) and we made it to the brink of the upper falls (1/8 mile), and the brink of the lower fall (3/8 mile). The last hike was super steep, windy, and slippery. Although we got a great view at the bottom, the hike back up is short but strenuous.
Certainly go see this sight while in Yellowstone National Park. It's an incredible viewing. We hiked and ate a picnic lunch overlooking the falls. Gorgeous!
Grand canyon of Yellowstone is very picturesque. Different colors - yellow, red, white, pink etc. Must see!
You hear about the geysers but not about the beautiful geography of the park! The trips down to the overlooks are key!
No trip to Yellowstone would be complete without a visit to this Grand Canyon. The views exceeded my expectations.
Although it not enormous like the Grand Canyon, definately worth visiting it. From the lookout it is magnifcent enough.
A must stop as you tour Yellowstone, so glad it was included as part of our guided bus tour with Caravan tours.

On the last day of our vacation to Yellowstone we went to the canyon area of the park. The view from Artist's Point was amazing and made for several photo opportunities on the vivid canyon, Crystal River and majestic lower falls of the Yellowstone River. We skipped the trail to the brink of lower falls which has a reputation for being difficult and unsafe. However, we didn't feel cheated at all. The views from Lookout Point and Red Rock Point were outstanding!

Don't miss what ever you do the stunning Grand Canyon of Yellowstone. The waterfall cascades down and is a joy to behold. It is beauty at its best and shows the raw power of nature. The canyon is approx 20 miles long, 4,000 feet wide in parts and 1,000 deep. The canyon walls and rocks are multi colours of red, orange and gold as basically the rocks oxidise ( rust ) over time. It gets very very crowded so if you can go around 7-8am. Its a must see site.
What a sight. You could just sit and take it all in it's so beautiful. Nice walking path. Take your time and enjoy.
Absolutely gorgeous. When you go back and look at your photos, they look like Watercolor paintings the way the colors blend.
Make certain to do the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone! breathtaking views. I posted and people commented they must be looking at NATGEO:)

Amazing, amazing, amazing. Do the hike and get down to see the upper and lower falls. The hike to the upper falls is a bit challenging but take your time and it's well worth it. Lower falls are less strenuous.
take the time to walk down and check out the waterfall. incredible. I could not believe how stunning
Beauty in top of beauty. I wish Tom’s trail was open but misding the long hike allowed us to experience the whole northern loop.
Although awesome and well worth the time, I was surprised to see this at number 1. The views are great and the waterfall is awesome. Do your research though as some trails get closed at times.

Yellowstone offers a vast range of beautiful sights and I was surprised this area is rated the best on TA. Yes it “nice” but not as dynamically different as other areas of the park. Very accessible, very busy and parking limited at each location on the trails around the Canyon - so get there early. Apart from the views we say mountain goats and nesting kestrels.
Worth the crowds to see. Magnificent views. Go on the hike to get away from the crowds & you will be rewarded. There are no words for how spectacular this is.
A small but deep canyon, not like the know Grand Canyon, worth a visit, great rock structures, there are 2 rims to visit , another place to see in Yellowstone
I walked through many points along the loop road and enjoy the glorious views. I highly recommend this place for everyone. It's beautiful and stunning.

This is a very cool feature within Yellowstone. We spent the afternoon hitting the trails and overlooks on the North Rim. After dinner, we went back out and hit the sites (that were open) on the South Rim. You should hit all of them as they give you a different view of this awesome feature. There is a trail restoration project going on right now. It looks likes some currently closed trails will open in August 2018 and some currently open will close for work. You can check their website for closure updates.
Hike the south rim for fantastic views. Trail head starts at the parking area for the lower falls viewing. Easy Hike. Two miles round trip. Breathtaking views of the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone.

The Grand Canyon home was a highlight on our visit to Yellowstone. This is not to be missed. We hiked about 75% of the way down as we had our 4 year old with us and it was our second hike of the day. I would say it is totally doable for younger kids and worth the hike...just be cautious as it is one of the longer ones and the hike back is all uphill.
If you have to see only one thing in Yellowstone it should be this one.There are multiple view points to see this place. Inspiration point is the best.

There are many points along the grand loop road for you to pull off and take in the glorious views of the canyon. The raging water has a beautiful green color and if you arrive around sunset, you will be rewarded with even more beautiful views! This was our highlight of our Yellowstone trip.
A little crowded but the falls with the hills beside colorful as it can be will take your breath away !. A must visit if you love waterfalls.
Stunning and beautiful. Get ready to stop a lot to take pictures. Majestic and completely worth visiting.
Fantastic scenery for camera buffs. The car park was close by the sights but should be avoided in the middle of the day when all spaces are full.
The views were amazing. The paths made it easy to see much of the canyon. Best time to go is after 6 a lot less people.

We visited about 7 at night. I highly recommend coming at this time. There was no traffic jam getting to the parking lot like when we drove by earlier. The view of the falls at Artist point looks like a green screen backdrop. It looks so beautiful it is unreal. While we were there we saw a rainbow on the opposite end of the canyon from the falls.

places_url_reviews_title: A big hole in the ground.
places_url_reviews_comment: When you see the big hole in the ground, you will want to take lots of pictures. It's just the natural thing to do. The colors of the rock are beautiful. Be careful, it is a big drop to the bottom. There are short rails, but nothing to keep you from stepping over if that's what you want to do. This is nature at it's finest.
Absolutely worth a visit! Beautiful views. The hardest part is the parking. Worth exploring the whole area.

What a great view. I wish the south rim trail was open when we visited in June -the North Rim was crowded and I heard the views are not as spectacular but they are still amazing. There is a strenuous hike going back up near the rim - so bring water.
This area has many things to see and is a must. Aside from Artist point, Brink if the Falls is a great visit. I’d highly recommend that side stop.

We hiked both the lower falls and upper falls trails with our 11 and 12 year old children. We also did the Red Rock trail. All of the hikes we did at the canyon offered spectacular views. Just remember that in the case of these trails, what goes down must come up... we were exhausted but it was well worth it!
I don't think it's possible to take a bad picture of these views. Definitely worth every view you can take in. Absolutely awe inspiring.

places_url_reviews_title: Well worth the visit but unfortunate closure in south rim
places_url_reviews_comment: The canyon is beautiful and views of the falls were terrific. Artistic point wonderful. Only disappointed that the south rim area where Uncle Tom’s trail is located was closed.
There's construction underway at Old Tom's trail. Parking is difficult due to the construction however the views are worth the extra hassle. Not for the faint of heart or folks scared of heights.

We had visited the Grand Canyon in Arizona, so we did not know what to expect! Of course, there is no comparison, but each canyon is beautiful in its own way! Make sure you stop and see the grand views!
Must see while in Yellowstone Park. Will take your breath away. Lots of history in this park. All families should bring their children.
beautiful views, hike is about 20 mins on the North rim. South rim recommended (Artist's point especially).
Can't say you went to Yellowstone and not stop to see the Grand Canyon. Simply beautiful, easy for anyone to get to from the parking lot.

places_url_reviews_title: Go early or end of day, worth the agony of parking even if mid-afternoon
places_url_reviews_comment: Parking is the difficult part of this attraction. It's not as if you have a lot of options for parking down the street and walking. Just drive around the circle until someone leaves and you can take their place. The good news is, if you have someone in your party that has mobility issues, you can take this slowly and get there to see the falls. Don't try to use a walker - use a cane. It's a stunning sight, an amazing, powerful waterfall. If you don't have mobility issues, the hike to Point Sublime (a dirt foot path that takes off up from the paved area) is worth the hike for more remarkable beauty, wow color... but it's a hike in all senses of that word.

places_url_reviews_title: Obviously a must do and worth the drive to Canyon if you're in the area
places_url_reviews_comment: Based on all of the reviews and pics, this one is obviously a must-see. Try to hit it early morning or later afternoon to avoid the always-present mass of people. But, we noticed that things really picked up in the area late morning/after lunch.

places_url_reviews_title: Great view, do it if you are in Yellowstone.
places_url_reviews_comment: Great view, pictures speak for themselves. Sufficient park. Do the hike and you get even better views. Choose your time because trails down can be wet or iced out and closed.
Such a beautiful Canyon. Artist point is where you can get beautiful photos. Make sure to see both sides.
You can't come to Yellowstone and miss this . . . it's a mini Grand Canyon. Beautiful colors, birds (osprey), massive waterfalls. Take all the rim trails, they're worth it!

Viewed from both south and north rim. The falls were spectacular due to the large amount of snow melt in early June. go early in the morning or in evening so you can get a parking space and view when less crowded
We visited the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone during a photo safari. Our guide got us to the falls when there is a rainbow present. Very nice place to visit.

My wife and I stopped at the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone on our trip to the national park. It's a pleasant walk from the parking lot to the viewpoint, not to mention a great opportunity to stretch your legs after all the driving. The view is amazing.
If you're photographically minded, this is very similar to the other Grand Canyon in that the canyon itself is rather wide with the water (details) being a bit distant. The difference is that here you'll likely want to capture some of those distant details. The viewpoint is a bit small so you'll have to work around the other spectators.
Plan on spending 45-90 minutes here.

We stopped off at all the viewpoints that were open (some were closed). All are worth doing and give slightly different views of the Canyon and falls.
It’s just amazing seeing the volume of water that goes over the falls.
Lower falls are definitely more spectacular.
The trails to and from the viewpoints are quite steep.
This was the highlight of all the sites in the park. Took tons of pictures. The walk from the parking lot was very close.
Very impressive site to visit. We made a few stops alongside the road. Take your time and take a deep breath to enjoy.

places_url_reviews_title: Rainbow of the Lower Falls on my iPhone
places_url_reviews_comment: New to Yellowstone - went on a "photo" tour through Xanterra. Wonderful wayto see Yellowstone. Our guide/driver had many years of experience in the Park as well as a photographer. Here is my photo with filter (taken by the guide) of the Grand Canyons of Yellowstone - Lower Falls. Amazing.

Be prepared to do some walking here. There are a lot of different access points for both the upper and lower rim, but as with everywhere in the park, are all extremely crowded. Some of the viewing spots required a steady hike uphill and downhill, but totally worth viewing if you're able to.

Stopped here as a part of the Yellowstone National Park Circle of Fire tour(book through NP website). Driver dropped us off as parking is a crush. The views are hard to put into words-pictures cannot accurately portray the majesty and beauty of this location. Make sure you get to the smaller upper falls area also
Thoroughly liked the view. There was not much rush during the time we were there. Could not spend much time as we were that day part of a guided tour.
I have been to Yellowstone many times. As always, the views from this vantage point is spectacular. It truly is natural wonder.

places_url_reviews_title: Well worth the long wait in traffic to park
places_url_reviews_comment: We saw this on the Circle of Fire tour from the Old Faithful Inn. Even the bus could barely find a parking spot. Expect a crowd of people at the overlook area. This a must see for a reason.
God is so good and the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone demonstrates His beauty! Take time to stop the busy and enjoy this view!

places_url_reviews_title: A bucket list place. Everyone should visit at least once!
places_url_reviews_comment: The Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone is one of the most spectacular sights on earth. The pictures do not even compare to seeing it in person. We drove around the upper and lower rims, stopping to get out and view at different designated spots. After hiking in the park all morning and stopping for lunch in Canyon Village, it was nice to drive around a bit. There was a bit of traffic, but we were always able to find a parking spot (We visited in mid-June). We really enjoyed stopping at the "Brink of the Upper Falls". You can park in a lot and walk a short distance to stand above the rushing water.

places_url_reviews_title: Absolute Must When Visting Yellowstone NP
places_url_reviews_comment: We spent a morning exploring the Grand Canyon of Yellowstone via a 5 mile South Rim Canyon hike. Our hike began with admiring the sublime canyon color and the drastic 308 ft drop of the Lower Falls from above. We then descended the 328 metal steps at Uncle Tom’s to the base of the Lower Falls before walking over to Artist point for yet another perspective. The hike then took us away from the crowds into bear country. With our bear spray in hand, we walked through wildflower scattered meadows, along Clear Lake and through the bubbling thermals and mud pots.

places_url_reviews_title: Such beauty -- beyond words to describe
places_url_reviews_comment: Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone is the top attraction in the park. Incredible falls, views, wildlife. Go early in the morning and enjoy perfection without crowds.

This is a must-see geological attraction! You can also get a great view of the waterfall and raging river. You may want to bring a jacket when it is cool. This place is also free. We had an amazing experience. Well worth the stop!

The Grand Canyon of Yellowstone is so breathtaking. While there are some trails, vantage points that are closed (Uncle Toms and Inspiration Point), the ones that are open offer amazing views. You really don't miss out on anything.
We very much enjoyed seeing this spectacular canyon with breathtaking views! It was certainly worth our time!
This was the most spectacular part of Yellowstone Park (in my opinion) and there are so many amazing sites!

North rim road is better as more place to park. Getting the south rim with artist point is ok but crowded (especially with the other part closed: uncle’s Tom)
Very good and different view from various point. Well maintained trails all paved
This is a picture perfect falls and canyon. Plenty of viewing points, even if some are quite a climb back up. Do not miss this!!
There is not much to add, just amazing and impressive! even in bad weather, quite a breathtaking overlook!

places_url_reviews_title: Amazing Place for View and Photos
places_url_reviews_comment: There were falls on both sides of the walkway area, so it was a 360 degree feast for the eyes! So much beauty to see, and the day was warm, sunny and breezy. Although I am a bit fearful of heights, since there were large rocks on the edges of the walkway, I was not too affected to enjoy what I was seeing. This is a gorgeous vista!
See the color of the rock in the canyon and you'll realize why they call this place Yellowstone. A remarkable geologic feature with an amazing waterfall. An easy path out to see the canyon.

I put photos of the best places I have seen on my walls. This will be one! It was hard to see much of it, since construction has closed some areas and my inability to do steep or long hikes but still, it is a super-nice view. We were there mid-day which helped light up both sides of the canyon for my favorite picture.

When you are driving Yellowstone take the time to drive up to Artists Point and the canyon
Notes. Keep kids away from canyon edge. Go all the way to top of parking lot and turn around the. Find parking. Bathrooms can be crowded drive down the way to Whytipi open bathrooms. Take the entire walk. Each view of canyon and waterfall is different and beautiful

places_url_reviews_title: One of the highlights of our trip!
places_url_reviews_comment: Truly spectacular! Make a day of it and stop at every look out and hike every trail from both sides. this waterfall is simply spectacular to see!
Words can't explain. This whole park is beautiful, but especially this point. It wasn't too crowded, parking was a breeze, and I could have stayed there for ages.

places_url_reviews_title: The most scenic view in Yellowstone
places_url_reviews_comment: Do not cut short the opportunity to take in the beauty of the canyon. If Old faithful is the most famous spot in the park this is the most scenic.
We were totally blown away by these crashing falls! Just spectacular. The ranger there was eager to answer our questions and the crowds made sure everyone got “their” picture. Must see!
Our entire family, youngest 14 months, went on a day hike in the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone. Everyone loved all the beautiful scenery that we saw! We couldn't take enough pictures!

The wet weather and a bout of altitude sickness with a family member prevented us from really exploring this on foot but what we could see was breathtaking. It was horribly crowded however, with good reason.

We visited this area twice. The views are breathtaking. Be sure to bring binoculars to look for wildlife, we saw an Osprey nesting on top of a very large rock. Be careful if traveling with children, there are areas with very low rock walls (ankle height) which were scary when small children were nearby. We spent about an hour taking in the views and walking to different vantage points, but you could just go look and leave within 30 minutes if you want.

It wasn't until I was here that I realized why "Yellowstone" is named as such. There really is yellow rock. Lovely views. Be aware that construction is going on and "Uncle Tom's" is closed until 7/4/18. We enjoyed the north and south rims. We went in the evening and again in the early morning in mid June and it wasn't crowded.

People often let go of this in favor of old faithful and other attractions. They are so mistaken! This is a true gem. Although you can view this from various lookouts, to get an up-close view of the canyon, I would highly advise doing a hike to the brim of lower falls. However, be advised that the hike is short... 3/8th of a mile... but steep with 600 ft elevation drop/gain. And mind you, ascent is the second half of the trail. But.... so worth it. Highly recommend.
We had a great hike on the lower rim. Unfortunately the other trails to the canyon were closed for updates.

It was really awesome place to see! The rock walls have a yellowish tint what was reason why the name of this national park is Yellowstone! Be careful when you will go there because in the summer season it is too crowded!

places_url_reviews_title: Like Grand Canyon of AZ, only smaller but up close!
places_url_reviews_comment: such beautiful scenery with great hiking to upper and lower falls. Not to be missed on a visit to Yellowstone. One of favorite parts of the park.

This place is so spectacular that we visited twice during the same trip to Yellowstone. We caught all the hues and colors at sunset. Then we had to go back for the sights and sounds during the day. Words dont describe this place but having just visited the Grand Canyon in March for me this was just more. I tried to attach some pictures but they dont really do it justice.

Go to artist point to get the view. The amazing waterfall. The whole valley is awesome. The parking was easy and there was plenty of room for viewing the falls, plus the upper falls was one of the few places in the park with good cell phone service.

places_url_reviews_title: Stunning views! Take a hike away from crowds!!
places_url_reviews_comment: Beautiful but crowded!! Breathe in the views and take some photos, then take a short hike to Point Sublime to get even better views and get away from the swarms of people at Artist’s Point! If you have small children, be aware that there are steep drop offs on the hike and children need to be watched closely. It is however family friendly if you keep that in mind. The hike is a lot of up hill hiking, but there were people of all ages and fitness levels on the trail.
Every part of Yellowstone is beautiful and this is no exception. Beautiful falls and scenery with a very nice Visitor Center.
The canyon takes you to another world almost. The fresh mountain air is so relaxing. You will want to stay and enjoy the sights and sounds as long as you can.

The Grand Canyon was so awesome and had easy short boardwalks to walk to see the canyon and the falls. Highly recommended and I would go the the Lowe falls as well as the brig of the upper falls. You will not be disappointed!
The views here are amazing. Love the rushing water and sounds. Although the walks along here are at a incline, they are not too difficult.
Incredible view. Take time to soak it in and enjoy such amazing Creation. My wife loved the views for pictures :)

An absolute MUST when in Yellowstone.
Sadly I was unable to get to the foot of the falls due to the snow.
But the upper view was superb. See photo!
We hiked along the beautiful south rim trail. Took us a little longer because we hadn’t adjusted to the higher elevations. Take lots of water with you.
Go there early in the morning. It has the best light and the fewest people. Inspiring and beautiful place.
Nice set up with informational signs and paved walkways; even my husband with limited mobility could walk to the first overlook

This is a heavy traffic area so patience is required. Dress warmly, especially on a windy day and watch your footing when walking and be mindful that the canyon is deep and guard rails sometimes lacking. Stay on the trail. the views are out of this world. An osprey is nesting on a pillar below the lower falls. The Falls themselves are distant unless you take the trail down to see them up close but well worth the view. Read up on the valley before you go. Must be seen to be believed.

Still beautiful but not as accessible as 15 years ago. Uncle Tom’s cabin and inspiration point were closed. I remember being able to walk up close around some canyon walls 15 years ago but could only see everything at a distance on this trip.

Our tour group had the opportunity to take two days to do both the upper and lower loops. The Grand Canyon was one many sites we had the pleasant of seeing, our guide don Mckenzie was very knowledgable of the park. If you ever visit Yellowstone contacting and using Don is a must. We all were just blown away of the vast beauty of GOD's creation. It was definitely a bucket list trip, hope to have an opportunity again
It was okay, but not fabulous. Not quite "grand". It was croeded and we were there before the "season". Expect huge crowds later.

Since I can't find an overall site for review of Yellowstone, I'll enter it here. Yellowstone has many wonderful attractions including the Grand Canyon. There are many warning signs throughout the parking about the dangers of animals and hot springs, HOWEVER there are few warning signs about other dangers. For example, the view of the falls from the southern rim has NO signs warning of the danger that exists from this viewpoint. They simply have some boulders about 2 feet high separating the visitors from the edge of the cliff. I personally saved a small boy that was climbing on them and came close to going over the edge, and who's parents weren't watching him. The loop road that goes through the park is very narrow in most places AND there are many, many miles of it in which there are no guardrails making it very treacherous and nerve racking driving. Sooo, if you don't like mountain driving you might want to think about taking a tour. The drive to this area from Tower Roosevelt is the worst, climbing very high up through the mountains. There are some guardrails but not near enough. Going south you are in the inside lane as you climb, but if you return this way, you will be in the outside lane and there are NO guardrails and there are steep drop-offs. The edge of the road is very close to the drop off. I am very disappointed by the management of this park. The roads should have been widened long ago AND many guardrails added. They focus so much on the dangers of animals that they forget about the other dangers that exist in the park for which nothing is being done. Parking in viewing areas is also very bad. There are millions of trees in the park and the park service is so bent on preserving the park, that they are stingy in chopping down a few trees to add more parking space, which I think is just ridiculous. While Yellowstone is a beautiful park, it definitely needs better management.

One of my favorite sites in Yellowstone. Beautiful, much to see and do for all ages. Hiking trails and opportunity to spend a short time here if you just want quick pictures or you can spend 1/2 day hiking and hanging out, etc.

The Canyon is spectacular. See it from the South Rim Trail, at Artist's Point, and also from the North Rim (with less viewing). The Lower Falls are 300 feet of beauty, surrounded by colorful rocks along the gorge like you won't see many other places.

Allow yourself the time to explore the north and south rim, the view from Artists Point is awesome and is the one you see photographed all the time. On the north rim go to the brink of both falls, to feel the energy of the waterfalls and round your visit off with the Grand View to take in the colours of the canyon.

We visited all available lookout points, and hiked South Rim to Point Sublime. Gorgeous! Spectacular! Very colorful! If it was up to me, I will call the park "Rainbow-stone" instead of Yellowstone.
Hike is easy and worth the effort, but very few people exploring that rout.
Do not miss seeing this while on your trip. This vista is awe inspiring and well worth the stop to view.

places_url_reviews_title: Most amazing thing I've ever seen!
places_url_reviews_comment:
Brink of Lower Falls was awe inspiring!
Can't wait to go back to go down the Uncle Tom's hike which is closed this year.

Wonderful. Exceeded all of my expectations. The day we visited it was raining and cold. We soon learned that keeps a lot of the crowds away. Dress in layers and be sure and take waterproof hiking shoes. Worth every penny.
This really is well worth the stop. Parking is difficult during the middle of the day, but be patient. There are multiple views of the canyon that allow you to avoid those with selfie sticks!
It’s so pretty here!! The colors in the rock are amazing and really is like a mini Grand Canyon. Beautiful!!

There was plenty of water so the waterfalls was spectacular!
The canyon is also fantastic...its a must see and a great photo op

Download the App GyPSy Guide for Yellowstone on your phone. The GPS on the app keeps your location as you drive and tells you information about upcoming sites on you route. You will not miss any of the beautiful places in Yellowstone. Also take a trip To Cody and Cooke City.
Absolutely gorgeous waterfall and lookout of water, the canyon, and overall just a breathtaking view.

places_url_reviews_title: Worth the hike But there are several closures at the moment
places_url_reviews_comment: Pretty frustrating to arrive for a hike and find that basically the entire South rim is closed to hiking. Uncle Toms was one of my missions that won’t be fulfilled on this trip (stayed to open in July). Even part of the North rim is closed. Still great views that can be seen from several spots, lower falls trail was open as was Artists. Several others were given suggested hikes by their lodges only to arrive and find the closures. Enjoy the beauty but be prepared to change plans!

This was one of my favorite stops in the park. It exceeded all expectations and our photos taken with just a cell phone we're like postcards. There are several stops with different views, and all had adequate parking although we didn't go in the busiest season. Highly recommended!
We loved the Grand Canyon of Yellowstone! We got amazing photos at Artist Point and the brink of the lower and upper falls allow you to get closer to the falls. Truly amazing site!!

places_url_reviews_title: Beautiful, but not fully accessible early in the season
places_url_reviews_comment: We visited in mid-May and were able to view the Grand Canyon of Yellowstone and falls from Artist Point, however, the most of the other viewing points weren't yet open. Still, it's a "grand" sight. The walk from the parking lot was easy.

A must!! In the morning there's a 15 minute window when the sun hits the falls and you get a wonderful rainbow. A photographer's dream. Be sure and visit both upper and lower falls. It's so beautiful and we felt humbled to be in the presence of this majestic waterfall.

places_url_reviews_title: My favorite place in the park.
places_url_reviews_comment: Stunning vistas on both sides of the canyon are worth the extra time to drive to. Make sure you hike down at least one of the trails to see it all from a different point of view. Be sure to see Inspiration Point! (It was closed for this visit, but the Grand view is a good second.

Sharing the area with quite a few others, I was still able to enjoy the views and take some stunning photos. Because of the time of year, not all options of viewing were open, but I was able to see the beautiful canyon with all the colors and textures.
Absolutely breathtaking. This was my whole family’s favorite thing to see in Yellowstone. I recommend taking the North Rim Trail around the canyon. It is very moderate.
the Trafalgar National Parks Tour allowed adequate time to enjoy the breathtaking and beautiful scenery here.
After viewing the upper and lower falls spend some time looking at the canyon. It goes straight down and you get a breathtaking view.
You must see this if you go to Yellowstone. Not the Grang Canyon, but a great place. Easy parking and walk.

It may not be as big as the Grand Canyon but it definitely packs an incredible visual punch. The canyon is full of amazing colors, two beautiful waterfalls, and there are usually some cool raptors flying around too. This is a must visit site when you come to Yellowstone.

The sight of this canyon and associated waterfalls was jaw dropping; not unlike the feeling when we first saw the Grand Canyon in Colorado. We visited the third week in May and found the water levels to be very high, the river was roaring. We opted to hike the ¾ mile down the steep train to the lower falls observation point located immediately next to the edge of the cliff the water drops off. The hike was totally worth the effort. The path still showed signs of the recent snow melt. In fact, the path to the upper falls was still closed. The large parking lot was mostly empty.

Worth the drive around both the rims. Take the time to get out and walk to the observation areas and take in the beauty. It was breathtaking. We were early in the season, so roads are a little dicey. Check with rangers , they are amazing resources!
First time visit to this world leading national park and you will not be disappointed in all you see before you.

You should see it yourself as worlds cannot explain everything and the feelings you get when you watch these,if you have time and trails are open just cover it by doing the trails and all the shades and colors are great
I wish I could provide any sense of the sights, feelings, sounds of this spot....but for me - it is impossible. It was a magical, spiritual moment that will live with me for the rest of my life.

It is worth walking down to the falls on the north rim - it takes about 10-15 minutes to walk down but the photo ops for the large waterfall and canyon itself are really worth it. It is a steep walk back but you can take breaks along the way.
Lookout point enables you to get good photos from the top of the canyon without walking down into the canyon - look out for the osprey nest in one of the high rocks as you look into the canyon.

The waterfall was really amazing and can't be missed. I hear there's a hike that you can actually get really close to it. A lot was closed off for us because we were there in May and there was still a lot of snow on the ground. DO not miss this area when you are in the park.

the falls are beautiful. There is an upper and lower so you must continue down the road to see both. The short walk out the points are worth it. The falls are dramatic and different viewing points are available for seeing a different perspective. Take your time and watch the drama unfold.

I had missed this last time we went to Yellowstone due to a water main breaking the road when coming from the North. Saw it and was inspired and awed by the grandeur of this majestic treasure! Very few places evoke the sense of wonder and delight that this magnificent canyon does in me. The Grand View overlook was much less crowded and the views are nearly as good as the Brink of the Lower Falls. Get your "been there, done that" shot at the Lower Falls and then move up to Grand View to drink in the splendiforous essence of Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone. A definite highlight of our trip.
Great Loop Road offers so many beautiful vistas. Take your time and stop whenever there is a parking area. Even if you aren't going to hike just enjoy the views.

We went just a day after west entrance was opened. This place is simply awesome, views are stunning. One of the most scenic places on earth especially when there is lost of ice and it’s a sunny day.
Must visit when in Yellowstone National Park.
Five stars...

places_url_reviews_title: This is worth to see but...
places_url_reviews_comment: You should not expect something like Grand Canyon, otherwise you will be very disappointed, although it is beautiful and lovely...

If you want to see beautiful landscape and waterfalls on your trip to Yellowstone, the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone will make for a great stop and photo opportunity. There may be others but the overlook we stopped at, had wonderful expansive views of the falls as well as the canyon walls carved out by the river. As I will suggest in any review of major park attractions, get there early since if the road to get there is open, its tourist season. So most scenic outlooks like this draw pretty big crowds which kind of takes away from the peacefulness you would get from this place without the crowds.

It is quite a hike down some of these steep rocky trails to see this canyon and river and I did gripe a bit about it but the views that you have when you get to a stopping point are so awesome and I did live through it all! LOL There are sheer drops with waterfalls and some geysers as well as the raging river carving the walls out over time. Just awesome!
There isn't anything I could say bad about visiting this park! It's beautiful, awe inspiring and humbles me.

The Yellowstone River's canyon often gets lost in the shuffle of geysers and roaming bison. Frankly, it wasn't very high on our list prior to our visit. Once there, however, we were quickly enamored with the place. It's stunningly colorful, and I wished I would have had more time to hike in the area and not just catching quick glimpses.

Definitely a beautiful display of sheer rock canyons with waterfalls traversing through creating the perfect backdrop for a spectacular photo opportunity. We didn't walk down to the lower areas as it was getting late in the day but in my opinion...you don't need to.
It is a awe inspiring display of nature that Yellowstone is so well known for.
Definitely don't miss out here...

places_url_reviews_title: The most beautiful place we saw
places_url_reviews_comment: Admittedly, our trip to Yellowstone was short and surfacey. We didn't have a lot of time and did the photo-op loop for the sake of a guest from Asia. Much of the rest of it was cool, but this was legitimately beautiful and I wish we had more time to explore but we had to hop into the car to drive to the next photo op. If we go back to Yellowstone, it will be to stay in the Old Faithful Lodge and spend more time here.
The waterfall is so cool and mist surrounds it. I loved it. You have to climb down a bunch of stairs and it can get scary, but the scenery is definitely worth it.
Nice walks available especially to see waterfalls from closer viewpoint. Lower waterfalls impressive, not totally frozen in the winter. Beautiful landscapes
It is deep, there are lots of trails one both sides of the canyon (you can easily walk and appreciate the perspective from the top)
This was a beautiful attraction, and place to stop and just enjoy the majesty of this park! Bring a camera, great hiking shoes, and plenty of water!

Amazing views from a number of points of the canyon and falls, we stopped off at Artist's Point as time was limited. Would have like to have walked more of the canyon itself, but the views from Artist’s were spectacular. Winter I bet is even better.

places_url_reviews_title: One of my favorites at Yellowstone NP
places_url_reviews_comment: Grand Canyon of Yellowstone definitely made my top two favorite of Yellowstone National Park. The view is breathtaking. We hiked down to the start of the waterfall. Somewhat steep hike, so good hiking shoes recommended, but the view is all well worth your time and effort.

This area of YNP is located at the point where the lower loop joins the upper loop, on the right or east side of the lower loop. The place is very crowded daily in the Summer so keep patient with the traffic jams that are experienced so frequently. The weather is also subject to change dramatically, as the rain came quickly and changed an 80 degree day into the fifties, with hail, thunder, and lightning within minutes!
There are two distinct areas to visit, the lower canyon view and the upper "ledge" walkway. The lower view provides spectacular views of both the Upper and the Lower Falls. You can walk part of the way onto the lookouts. In August of 2017 the other walkway was closed for the Summer due to construction.
The walk on the Upper Canyon road is the most spectacular since you can walk within feet of the Falls, as you watch the rushing water pass by only a few feet from you, just before the water tumbles down the very high Falls. This is possible only after a somewhat strenuous walk down many stone, wet stairs to the small balcony at the top of the Falls. On the ridge walkway you can see down over the deep cliffs into the Canyon's bottom below, and still get views of the Falls and other beautiful scenery. This area is a must-see for your visit to YNP.

There are many easy views from the rim that are great, such as Artist's Point or Grand View. However, my favorite view of the lower falls is from Red Rock Lookout. It does involve a bit of a hike down into the canyon on a well done trail. It is well worth the effort. If you are more ambitious, you can hike lower into the canyon and closer to the lower falls by hiking Uncle Tom's Trail. Also fine views. It is hard to go wrong at any of the canyon viewpoints. Note the canyon is great in any season, although in the winter or spring - snow can limit access.
It is always a joy to see the canyon in any season; in the winter, the snow is especially beautiful.
This area is one of my favorite places in the park. There's lots of hiking and viewpoints and the waterfalls are so beautiful.

A snowcoach tour leaves the Old Faithful Snow Lodge at about 8:00 and circles the parks stopping at many planned sights including viewing the Lower Falls of the Grand Canyon. It stops for scheduled heated restroom breaks and sights along the way. It also stops when animals are sighted and everyone can get out and take photos. A box lunch is provided and eaten in the Canyon visitors center so you can warm up. Coach is very comfortable and well heated. Coach holds up to 10 people.

The Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone is a 24 mi/39 km canyon between Tower Fall and Yellowstone Falls. There are 2 main drives:
1) North Rim Drive: Brink of Upper Falls Trail, Brink of Lower Falls Trail, Inspiration Point, Red Rock Point, Lookout Point, Grand View Point
2) South Rim Drive: Artist Point, Uncle Tom's Trail (closed until Fall 2019)
Hikers can opt to do the North Rim Trail (partially closed between Brink of Lower Falls Trail and Brink of Upper Falls Trail until Fall 2019) and South Rim Trail (closed until Fall 2019) instead of the drives.
My husband and I visited in August. As hikers, we were disappointed that we could not hike the South Rim Trail, including Uncle Tom's Trail, which takes you to the base of Lower Falls. However, we understand the importance of maintaining this natural beauty and hope to return when construction is completed. We did the North Rim Drive around 6pm on Saturday and the South Rim Drive around noon on Sunday. We recommend doing the drives either early or later in the day as there is limited parking. We had no trouble finding parking at the various view points on North Rim Drive at 6pm but had to park on the side of the road instead of the designated parking lot at Artist Point.
The Brink of Upper Falls Trail and Brink of Lower Falls Trail are 0.4 mi/0.6 km each and really do take you to the brink of the falls. While all the viewpoints were pretty, Artist Point was the most scenic and memorable. If you have time for only 1 viewpoint in Yellowstone, make it Artist Point.

Be sure to hike down to the platform at the top of the falls. It is AWESOME. It’s a decent way down and back up, but not all that strenuous and so amazing to stand where all that raw power is cascading over every second.

I was amazed by the size and beauty of this place. Hike down to the brink of the upper falls after you take a look around the top. Evening or mornings before 10 AM are the best, less crowded times to go.

places_url_reviews_title: Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone - a Yellowstone National Park MUST SEE !!!
places_url_reviews_comment:
On the list of the Top 10 things to see in Yellowstone NP...the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone is indeed wonderfully beautiful and majestic !!!
There are two drives/trails to do: one is the North Rim Drive, and the other is the South Rim Drive. You just have to do both !!! You will get fantastic views, up close and personal, of the Upper Falls, the Lower Falls and of course the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone, as you walk along the rim of each side of the canyon.
Make sure you the do Brink of the Upper Falls lookout, and the Brink of the Lower Falls viewpoint, be sure to do Lookout Point, Grand View...all on the North Rim. Then make sure you do the Upper Falls view, Uncle Tom's Point, Uncle Tom's Trail, and Artist Point...all on the South Rim.
Truly an incredibly wondrous creation !!!
Either go to Yellowstone NP in the Spring, before Memorial Day weekend, or in the early fall, after Labor Day weekend...if your schedule allows. You will avoid the huge tourist crowds, congestion, noise, and all that goes along with the summer crush !!! We went the first full week after Labor Day weekend, and the crowds were GONE. Easy to park, no congestion, in some places hardly any people, saw a lot of wildlife as they were content to come back into view now that the people had left. But be sure to bring layers of clothes, as temps can be comfortable during the day, but can be quite cold in the evening. We even experienced snow and freezing temps a couple of our days visiting !!!
Take lots of photos...Enjoy !!!

places_url_reviews_title: Beautiful Waterfall, higher than Niagra Falls.
places_url_reviews_comment: Take note this is should see. I was with a tour and just loved it. A great tour manager makes a big difference. There are many areas to see around the falls that the tour shows you. The bathrooms sre terrible at the Falls.

places_url_reviews_title: One of the most gorgeous places in the park
places_url_reviews_comment: This is certainly one of the most beautiful places in the whole Yellowstone Park, a place that is already full of breathtaking and unbelievable scenery. It's a tough hike, but definitely do Uncle Tom's Trail to the Lower Falls - it's simply amazing. In any direction you look, there are stupendous views. You can't take a bad photo here.

My partner and I had a magnificent all day tour on Christmas Eve day, a gorgeous sunny and cold day. Our guide was very friendly, upbeat and kept us well informed of the many sites we saw on this 8 hour journey. The views just kept getting better from Norris Geyser to the upper and lower falls of the Canyon to the wildlife surrounding Yellowstone Lake. There were several stops along the way for rest room and snack breaks and the tour price does include a box lunch. This was an ideal way to spend Christmas Eve day with crisp winter images that look like they just came out of a holiday postcard.
Our pictures bring back fond memories we will always treasure. Having been to Yellowstone the last 2 Christmas vacation, the Canyon Day Tour is my favorite and I would strongly recommend it. Please note that our day was sunny, about 8 degrees, and gorgeous blue sky.
It is not the real Grand Canyon, however, it is great in its own way, impressive and unique, like each and any other wonder of the park.

places_url_reviews_title: Amazing, breath-taking, spectacular...did I say amazing?
places_url_reviews_comment: I can't even begin to describe how wonderful the views are! The paths are well maintained and there are the occasional restroom facilities. We visited in October so it wasn't very busy. We packed a lunch and enjoyed it at a lovely little viewing station. I just can't say good enough things, it's amazing!

places_url_reviews_title: must go but make sure bring warm clothing
places_url_reviews_comment: The cayon is very pretty with different colors. We went on both rainy and sunny days, both were good. On the rainy day, the temperature dropped so much that we had to buy jackets from the shop near by.
Beautiful to see. If you are relatively fit, take the walk down to the waterfalls. It is spectacular. Walking back could be taxing, but it is worth it.
The canyon is nothing like the Grant Canyon on the Colorado.but is very interesting. There are some very colorful spots.
The Grand Canyon of Yellowstone has striking geography. You would not expect to see this in Yellowstone. The diversity of geography in Yellowstone is amazing.

The views of the Grand Canyon are gorgeous! It is definitely a must visit! I visited when there were fires in Montana, but thankfully it rained the previous night so the sky was no longer hazy. It is definitely one of my favourite spots in Yellowstone, I enjoyed this better than the geysers.
WOW, definitely worth the visit. I enjoyed seeing the Grand Canyon more than the geysers. The canyon is spectacular, love the colours and the waterfalls.
Well worth the effort to visit here. Scenery is spectacular. Be sure to get there early and miss all the big crowds.
In many ways much better than the famous geysers with the spectacular canyon cutting deep into the forest.
The downstream view of the lower falls is breathtaking. There was lots of free parking, and we'll maintained trails.
The trip to Yellowstone NP was my first. This vista was one of the definites on our trip. Gorgeous view! Parking is limited so go early and expect to wait for an open slot.

We visited this popular attraction early in the day. Parking was still available and the temperature was still on the cool side. There are several stops on each side of the canyon, some are closed for construction (Inspiration Point, part of the north rim trail, and Uncle Tom's Point). We stopped at Artist Point, Brink of the Upper Falls, Lower Falls, Lookout Point, and Grand View. My favorite was Artist Point, the views are excellent from here. Parking lots at most of the spots are big enough for several cars. Most of the sites are within easy walking from the parking lots. The only exception is Brink of the Lower Falls, the trail drops steeply about 600 feet to the falls. Some reviews compare this to the Grand Canyon in Arizona, but there is no comparison. This is unique and beautiful in its own way. This is a must stop when visiting the park. If you can only see one part of the canyon, I recommend Artist Point. I also recommend arriving early to avoid the major crowds.

places_url_reviews_title: A view from the canyon protected this place as a national park
places_url_reviews_comment: Not only are the views stunning, but they are legendary and should not be missed. The walk is easy and though it is a very popular place, relax and go with the flow and you will be able to enjoy this beautiful place
Visiting Yellowstone wouldn't be complete without checking in the Grand Canyon. As the name implies, it is big and impressive. Rightly so.

places_url_reviews_title: One of my favorite places in Yellowstone
places_url_reviews_comment:
This is a must see if you have limited time.
We primarily experienced this through Artist Point, which gives you a view of the brush like colors on the canyon walls, and then the amazing lower falls and the river which carves a beautiful turquoise ribbon through the golden walls of the canyon. We also visited the brink of the upper falls, which let you get a bit more up close and personal to the frothing waters!
Several stops along the side of the road or you can walk over from the Canyon Visitor Center. Look for the osprey nest.
Super cool. Great place. Beautiful sights. We were there early October, chilly, some snow. Don't miss site. Free. Decent walk. Other areas to walk out on.

places_url_reviews_title: A must see when visiting Yellowstone NP
places_url_reviews_comment: Any visit to Yellowstone would not be complete without a visit to the canyon and falls along the Yellowstone River. I recommend arriving early to beat the crowds. See it from both the north and south rims. Then drive south along the river’s path thru Hayden Valley and you will most likely be rewarded with wildlife sightings!
