the cayon has many different color and it looks like a big painting, lovely to see it
I had no idea what an enormous canyon & waterfalls are in Yellowstone! Loved getting so close to upper & lower falls. Absolutely beautiful!

We visited the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone on our Circle of Fire tour and it was an incredible sight. We spent about 15 minutes there, which was a sufficient amount of time to look around and take pictures. Definitely a worthwhile stop while in the park.

places_url_reviews_title: One of the most beautiful spots I've ever seen
places_url_reviews_comment: The GCoY is stunningly beautiful! Any place you go around it has beautiful views and great photo ops. This is a must see place in Yellowstone....if you don't go here you're crazy!

places_url_reviews_title: The canyon and falls are breathtaking!
places_url_reviews_comment: Make sure you do the switchback walk down to the lower falls. We were tired but did it anyway and couldn't have been happier we did. The rover is gushing and so powerful. You get such different perspectives as you explore around.

Nice place to visit, but bring your camera. Always crowded and a little difficult to navigate. But once your in position, let the shutter fly. Early morning viewing will provide a opportunity to see a rainbow in the pool at the bottom of the falls.
A breathtaking view of this Grand Canyon of Yellowstone is another a must see place. The landscape is so beautiful, however during our visit (May 2017) the lower trail is close for renovation.

Find red rock trail
Do it
Be patient on parking far past entrance are usually places
Be prepared for rain showers
Have good nonskid shoes no flip flops here!
It looks like a painting
Rocks have lots of color
Keep your coffee cups as refills at general store are cheaper than buying with new cups

We hiked on the south side of the canyon although the South Canyon trail is under construction so we had to start at Artists Point. Still this was a great trail and we added a loop to Lily Pad Lake, geothermal area and Clear Lake. Then we drove the North side of canyon stopping at the various short trails and overlooks incredible pictures. Do not miss this

Now folks may differ with me on this one. But frankly I was extremely impressed by what I saw here. In my not so humble opinion, this place can give the Grand Canyon a serious run for it money when it comes to grandeur!
Spectacular falls worth visiting. It gets very crowded so I would recommend early morning or later evening.

If you go to Yellowstone this is a must see and nice hike around both north and south rims.
Trick is to do the main sightseeing spots either early morning or later in the evening
.... or be ready to be frustrated while seeking parking or just being way too crowded.
My wife and I saw all the attractions we wanted to with out the crowds by going early parking & then hitting the hiking trails before the crowds arrived.
we would get back to parking spots ready to leave to find big crowds and long lines of people waiting to find parking ... I said to myself that I would not being having any fun if that was the way I spent my vacation....
A little planning and preparation will go a long way in Yellowstone.

places_url_reviews_title: Very beautiful waterfall with great view.
places_url_reviews_comment: The lower falls was very beautiful and a great place to take pictures with great view. Unfortunately the upper falls road was closed for construction and we could not visit it. But the hiking trail was open for the upper fall, but it was a little messy with dirt. So we decided not to go for the hike.
Of the areas to visit, this one ranks up there. Go to Artists Point to see the falls. We tried Inspiration Point, but the road was closed to access it.
This canyon and waterfall was amazing. So many colors thru the canyon walls. Pictures just cannot compair to standing there and taking in the beauty
Beautiful! Amazing wildlife, cool hiking, awesome scenery (geysers etc). Nice shops for souvenirs and the park rangers and staff were always cheerful and willing to help or provide advice.

places_url_reviews_title: Beautiful but horribly crowded late morning/afternoons
places_url_reviews_comment: We got here early and beat the crowds. By the time we left the line to get in was all the way back to the main road. We hiked around the south rim, and got off the beaten track by hiking the Wapiti trail to the start of the trail by the main road (had someone pick us up). We only saw a few others once we got away from the falls which were amazing, btw.
Got there and it was empty! Took a chopper tour which was highly over priced ($500) for a couple. Great views. Stayed at the Williams RV park.

Sublime is short and pretty easy to get to. It is a path that leads you along the rim of the canyon. If you hate heights....it might not be for you.....but it is totally safe and offers the greatest views!!!
You should visit this place. The sight of the falls along with the color contrast and combination makes this place a must see spot in Yellowstone
Really nice. Do the hike to brink of the lower falls if you are able. Is about 1/2 mile and a decent incline. I'd say any able bodied person could do it. Really worth it.

This is a photographer's delight. The yellow, red and dark rocks are the color and the rushing water is the symphony. Get here early in the AM or just at sunset to avoid the crowds and have time to soak in the energy of the place without a hundred chattering adults and screaming kids in your face.

This is definitely one of the best views (of many!) in Yellowstone. The colors make it a breathtaking sight. Try to go early in the morning or last thing in the evening for the best views and lowest crowds for pictures!

Started early at Artist Point for a view of the falls at sun up---gorgeous!! Hiked from there along the South rim Trail to Uncle Tom's Trail---Then down the stairs to the lookout point---up close and personal with the falls. Very tough down and back up hundreds of steep stairs and back to the parking lot. Went over to the North Rim for trails of the Brink of Upper Falls and Brink of Lower Falls----then on to the North Rim trail through Red Rock (once again very steep down and back up)---then Lookout---Grand View--all giving a different perspective to the falls. Approx. 10 miles total that gave numerous vantage points for view of the falls--even saw Ospreys in a huge nest at top of a rock formation. Start early as these trails get crowded later on----Parking in this area is a challenge--we found it easier to park once on each Rim---and hike all the trails on that side then back to the car. Carry plenty of water and snacks if you choose to combine trails into longer hikes. It limits the need to keep returning to the car for supplies and finding new parking spots.
Grand Canyon of Yellowstone is a very appropriate name---worth spending an entire day there!!

My husband grew up visiting this place but even with his stories over the past years I still had no idea how incredible this was. We visited the lower Falls side only. This was one of the more crowded places in the park but it was early afternoon so that was expected. If you only have 1 day in the park add this to your list. There is a short hike down to the falls which I was able to do in sandals. My kids raced back up but they are in great shape- may be tough for elderly. There are some places to take a break though.

We loved the farthest lookout but the trail leading away was amazing. The hike is very simple and you will only have several stairs equivalent spots that require no skill.......and you will be by yourself since most don't recognize the trailhead from the falls viewing area.

Although not as deep or wide as "the" Grand Canyon, this had a more intimate feel to it and so in it's way was just as impressive.
You can drive or hike along both the South and North Rim's. There are numerous overlooks and trails that provide a different perspective all within a few miles. Some of these were closed for renovation work on trails and roads when we visited, so check beforehand.

Yellowstone had such diverse landscapes within a short drive. The canyon is one of the must-see places. It has many pull-offs along the way. Uncle Tom's was closed so it was extra crowded at Artist's Point. Brave the traffic jam and you will be rewarded. Parking gets really congested. The earlier you can go, the better. Also, include the scenic drive on your trip. It's worth it. Then stop for a bite at Canyon Lodge. The scenic drive ends next to the entrance.

places_url_reviews_title: Very NIce with Great Walk along the South Rim Trail
places_url_reviews_comment:
Great place to visit. The canyon is quite spectacular but it is not the Grand Canyon. There is very nice hike from the Chittenden Bridge along the South Rim Trail passing the Upper and Lower Falls to Artists Point – it was not that busy along the trail except near Uncle Tom’s Point and at Artist Point. Nice colors and rock formations as well as the two falls.
Well worth a visit especially if you take the South Rim Trail.

Of all the landscapes I have seen till date, the Grand canyon of Yellowstone, with the Upper and Lower falls of the Yellowstone river included, is the Grandest!!
Prepare to spend at least 3 to 4 hours here as you need time and energy to hike the brinks of both upper and lower falls.. its totally mesmerizing to watch the power of both these falls ... Lower falls being the better of the two!!
This is really worth a trip or two to see both sides of the canyon. The stained walls are worth a number of pictures as are the waterfalls.

This is another one of those features of the park that you don't really see until you're sitting on top of it. The views into the canyon are beautiful and very picture postcard. Definitely not to be missed
We enjoyed seeing this canyon although some of the access points were closed off due to re-building of the trails. It is a lovely site, very accessible. Also has restrooms, hiking trails.
Really unbelievable beauty. Like a postcard. Good trails to hike and soak it all in. Plenty of picture taking opportunities! Outstanding!
Lots of geological history on view in addition to beauty. But we should be ashamed of how the NPS, our employees, maintain the extremely limited and horrific facilities.

places_url_reviews_title: Don't miss any of the views
places_url_reviews_comment: Make sure to hike on both N & S side of canyon. The views are stellar. This has to be a must on any Yellowstone visit.
Breath taking view and a must see. Parking can be a challenge so try to go early morning or later in the afternoon. Take your patience with you! It is worth the wait.

places_url_reviews_title: Yellowstone Grand Canyon - Trail and Road Closures - Summer 2017
places_url_reviews_comment:
Based on best 100 hikes in Yellowstone, we were hoping to complete the 3.2 mile shuttle hike from Wapati Lake Trailhead and parking area - just south of Upper Falls on the Yellowstone River, ending at Inspiration Point and including Uncle Tom's Trail.
The trail between Wapati Lake and Uncle Tom's Trail is closed. Uncle Tom's Trail is also closed. The car wait to get to Artist Point was at least 30 points, due to high summer traffic. With limited cell phone coverage, it was a bit of a big problem, as signage was very limited as to the closures. Having dropped off our group before taking our cars, we found that the trail was closed, resulted in our party being separated.
In the end, we returned on another day, earlier in the morning before the traffic going to Artist Point was so backed up. (We were trying to do this about 11 am on June 30). The ranger later told us that between 9 and 5, the road to Artist Point is at least 30 minute backup.
The view is truly spectacular and iconic, so you cannot dismiss it. My best advice, based on other travelers would be to park at Wapati Lake - take the trail to Wapati Lake, then cut over to Uncle Tom's Trail. Find the trail to Artist Point ( the lower 1 mile is open). Unfortunately, you would then need to send someone back (2 miles+) to get a car and wait in line to pick up others.
Ironically, when we did visit the Northern Rim on July 3, there were people on Uncle Tom's Trail and the stairway down to view the Upper Falls. Not sure if it had suddenly opened or more likely - groups were dismissing the "closed" signs.
We walked the south rim trail. Many places to stop and view the canyon and river below. This is a must see in Yellowstone. You need to take the Uncle Toms Trail, I'll leave that review next.

We stopped by both lower and upper falls.
One thing that I really would like to raise a flag was the look out places were not 100% safe for toddlers or younger kids.
The fence was made for adults' design (small kids may be able to sneak inside and may have a chance to fall off); So adults should hold hands tightly and take very good care of young ones.
The views were gorgeous - people may be confused by the name of Grand Canyon, which is totally different look- but Yellowstone's Grand Canyon is namely Grand Canyon, which offers different charms.
Upper falls' lookout was easy as it's only 0.3mile walk from the parking lot but lower falls could show great landscape.
Highly recommend to see both ones for differences.

When we visited, 3 of the viewing areas were closed for renovations so the viewing areas that were open were extremely crowded and parking was almost impossible. However it is a beautiful area with amazing waterfalls. Oh and we saw osprey on their nests in this area as well. The rock formations here are unlike any we have seen anywhere else.
Our favorite spot in Yellowstone. Breathtaking amazing waterfalls and views. Hike down Uncle Tom's trail- a few hundred steps down. The view cannot be beat.
We enjoyed all of Yellowstone, but the Grand Canyon views are stunning! We every got to view the osprey nest and the momma watching out for her 3 chicks! Must see.
There's really not much to say other than it's a great photo opportunity and there's a beautiful waterfall. There are three stops and we hit the middle one which provided a lovely view.

places_url_reviews_title: It is Canyon - Beautiful After you Find Parking
places_url_reviews_comment:
1. It can be seen from many places so don't panicked. First park and them see.
2. If you are not careful you could be victim of Fender/Bender.
3. It is mostly Yellow in color as park name suggest Yellow Stone.
4. Many photo opportunities
Visited park on bus tour which was excellent. Great guide. Hit all the high points in the park and had a very good time
Between Mt. Washburn and Roosevelt Lodge. Scenic overlook. Very accessible and well maintained paths.

The Grand Canyon of Yellowstone is a sight worth beholding. Though not as vast as the Grand Canyon in Arizona, it is still a natural womder to behold. Great hiking around the rim or if you just want a peek from the top to the waterfall. This is one canyon they figure was really carved out from the river running through it.

places_url_reviews_title: Another beautiful part of the park
places_url_reviews_comment: There was so much to do in this area. We took in a few trails, some water falls and lots of amazing views. We got there around noon and the traffic was not bad. We got lots of nice pictures of the fall and even say an osprey nest on a ledge with babies in it.

This was my favorite part of Yellowstone (with the animals a close 2nd). Unfortunately it was one of the last things that we saw so we didn't get to spend as much time here as I would've liked. I would recommend going here early and take your time to go to a couple different vantage points to really appreciate it. I went on the trail that takes you right next to the waterfall and it is just amazing. The trail is a little sketchy but me, my 5 year old and two 7 year olds did pretty good.
Gorgeous views, great hiking trails, lots of parking, safe trails. We enjoyed a quick hike to see the beautiful water and scenery.

Your trip to Yellowstone would not be complete if you don't go and see the beauty of the Canyon. Either go early in the morning or in the evening to avoid the larger crowds. We also enjoyed the hikes that were there, but hiking is not necessary to get a good view of the Canyon, river or the Lower Falls.

places_url_reviews_title: Great place to take a family picture.
places_url_reviews_comment: This place really has a fantastic view. And a neat story behind it. One of the top three places to visit when you're in Yellowstone. But it is crowded and hard to park. Be prepared to wait a bit.
Great waterfall. But go early in morning - gets very crowded. Just a short walk from parking lot. Make sure you have a camera

Old Faithful is what you hear about most, generally, related to a visit to Yellowstone. I found the Grand Canyon to be much more impressive. We saw it from a distance down the river (not the closer vantage point) and, even from that distance is was incredibly impressive. The sheer power of the water was daunting and there were a couple of great vantage points plus as lovely shaded picnic/sitting area nearby. Well worth the parking hassle to see it!
Just WOW! The canyon and the falls were breathtaking. This is a must see at Yellowstone. We weren't able to hike the Uncle Tom steps but the Artist Point gave us the money shot with no problem!

While visiting Yellowstone National Park, we had a very nice view of the Grand Canyon and Lower Falls from Artist's Point.
Great lookout, highly recommended!
The views from the ramps are spectacular and beautiful, the yellow walls of the canyon are impressive.
This is absolutely beautiful! The kids even enjoyed the pretty view during a rain storm!e I wish we would have had more time.
This is a great hike but with the mountain air it may take you a bit longer to get back up than it sis to get down to it.

My second time here but i'm always amazed at the wonder of it all.. I could stand and look at it for hours.. Watched creatures enjoying it also.. The colors of the canyon's are so beautiful.. Can't wait to go back..

places_url_reviews_title: So much to see, so little time
places_url_reviews_comment: We enjoyed the canyon area of Yellowstone more than the geyser attractions. So many trails and scenic driving roads. If you go here, do not miss the upper and lower brink of the falls. For us, where we love waterfalls, this was the best thing in all of Yellowstone.

places_url_reviews_title: One of the two highlights of the park
places_url_reviews_comment: the falls, the canyon itself, the colours, the trails, the whole experience is just fantastic, even with parts closed
This is one of the stops on the Grand Loop. Easy to admire from the Lookout Points. For the athletic, plenty of hiking opportunities and to see the Falls up close!

Awe inspiring views and hikes within walking distance of the Canyon Lodge. Be careful of the several strenuous hikes down to the brink of the lower falls...the altitude can make you winded very quickly.
Go early in the morning (730-8a) to avoid the crowds as parking is limited.

It's quite an awe inspiring sight.
We also took the hike down to the brink of the lower falls. I would not recommend this for anyone with walking difficulties or health issues. There are quite a few switchbacks and the uphill can be long and difficult. But you get right next to the falls and is totally worth it!!!
Stay at the overlook up top for views of the canyon if you can't do the hike.
We just took in the views from the upper falls...spectacular! Will return when our children are older and we can do the full hike and see it all. But so glad we at least got a glimpse!

Do not go here unless it's before 10. It gets so busy during July and August. Artist point is a precarious hike that parallels the canyon until you get to a set of wooden steps that lead you to the bottom of the falls. Not a great hike for young kids. We also did the Lower Falls hike. It's steep and long but worth it. It takes you to the top of the Falls. There are breathtaking views. There are lots of benches along the hike so you can rest. We were a group of 5 from the ages of 12-65. Loved it. We also checked out the canyon visitor center. Lots of information, flush toilets, and tourist shops/eateries.

The Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone is beautiful. It's particularly impressive in early summer when there's large amounts of water flowing through it. The only downside is how crowded it gets. Try to arrive early to avoid the tour buses.
Get there early before the crowds and make sure you experience Uncle Tom's Trail! Breathtaking views and the power of the falls is incredible
This is one of the most spectacular views in Yellowstone. Do not miss this! Although parking lot was full, if you are patient a spot opens up often enough. Go early morning to avoid more crowds.

Best to get out there early as it gets packed quickly. The views were spectacular! We wanted to go to Artist Point and at the Brink of Upper Falls bust it was closed. We did not do Uncle Tom's Trail as we could see lots from the observation points. From other side We could see it's very seep climb to come up. Lookout Point and Grand View point gave us great views of the canyon below. Inspiration Point and Inspiration Point road are closed for reconstruction: expect completion in fall 2017. Uncle Tom's Point and Parking Area are closed for reconstruction: expect completion in fall of 2019 This deprived us to go there. ( We read this at site of YS).May be we will visit again in 2020.

Stunning views, but the crowds take away from it a bit. Great for pictures, the sides of the canyon are beautiful tones of yellow and red. If I came back again I'd set aside more time to hike along some of the nearby trails.
You should definitely hike the trail from Wapiti Lake to Artist Point. Make sure you check current maps so you're aware of closures.

Parking can be a bit of tricky thing in this area during prime time. That being said, it is totally worth it. We entered on the East side of Yellowstone and drove all around Yellowstone for the day and exited on the West side. We saw bison, elk, and deer as well as other fantastic things....but nothing tops the Grand Canyon of Yellowstone. Be sure you stop here and check it out.

places_url_reviews_title: Awesome watefall with many viewing options.
places_url_reviews_comment: Both the North and South side of the falls offer trails and options to get closer for views. Some are very strenuous. All of them are rewarding. This place is gorgeous.

I didn't bother to read their reviews because they can't be taken seriously, but I see that a few people rated this as poor or terrible. Makes me wonder if they were blindfolded or in a coma at the time. It can be overly crowded, but this has to be one of the most impressive canyons on earth. Yes, it's dwarfed by the THE Grand Canyon in Arizona, but when you stand at the brink of the Upper and Lower Falls and feel the ground rumble beneath your feet and watch the tons of water tumbling into the abyss below, it's a humbling experience.

The canyon never disappoints. But several trails and overlooks were under construction. So it was hard to get the full effect. Call ahead if planning a trip. Maybe construction will be finished by 2018.
This was one of the best sights of the park! It was incredible to see "the grand canyon" so far north. It is accessible to all ages. It is a must see.
If you plan to visit, go early, when it's not crowded, it's worthwhile going to. Might be able to see wild animals too
This was a beautiful not to be missed portion of Yellowstone. The Canyon. It was a beautiful wonder. The walls are so tall with the water rushing below!

This grand canyon has the colors of geologic formations of eons past along with the thunderous Yellowstone River that rushes through it. The falls can be accessed in a couple of points. There is even a hike to the bottom of the Upper Falls. Follow the road to the Grand View and you can see the Upper and Lower Falls cascading through the canyon. While there, be quiet and listen to the sounds of nature and the falls. This wonder of nature is breathtaking.

This is really a must do. In Yellowstone you expect the thermal features mostly, but this is a view unexpected. Easy walk from the parking lot, which wasn't that crowded in May but I understand can be quite packed later in the summer. Restrooms available in the parking lot (pit toilets)

We drove down South Rim road to the end where there are several ways to see the canyon and falls. This area seems to be the most popular in Yellowstone aside from Old Faithful but with about 1/3 the parking - so plan accordingly.
We could see people across on North Rim as well - so either way works. We went South Rim because of the easy access to Uncle Tom's Point to overlook the upper falls - then off to Artist Point to overlook the lower falls. A mile long hike beyond took us to Point Sublime and a fantastic overlook with 10% of the crowds. People tend not to venture too far beyond the main areas.
To go down into the Canyon area vs. look from the top - there are a lot of stairs - yet this isn't necessary to get the grandeur.
To see both stops and take the trails - allow at least 2 hours; probably 3

The hotel is located halfway between the Lamar valley and Haden valley where most of the animals are. The breakfast is excellent and relatively economical. The area itself has buffalo, deer, elk, bears, and sometimes wolves. The two biggest water falls are within walking distance.

On the day of our visit, it was raining and windy. And yet we could still feel the mist from the waterfall, and the wind coming off the water and up the canyon walls was strong enough to blow your hat and glasses away. This is a beautiful pull-off in the park. The sound of the rushing water is awe-inspiring. Such raw power!

Each turn of the park you find something different, interesting and most of all beauty. It's a most stop and you can see a lot just from the roadside. I can't imagine what the view is like is you hike in. For these seniors that is out of the question. If you have a handicap or disability don't let that discourage you from seeing this beautiful park.

We enjoyed getting out and hiking the trails around this area. I've never seen the Grand Canyon in person, but the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone was impressive! There are several places to take pictures. As with most of Yellowstone, children should be watched closely. Some of the trail areas are a little steep, but manageable.

Worth the wait if you go to the Artist's Point!! We were not sure but stuck it out and very glad we did! (Backed up traffic due to "small" parking lot.) I am afraid of heights but I just loved this place! Just amazing to look at! We also saw it from the Falls.
The Grand Canyon of Yellowstone was awesome! It was so much like the Grand Canyon in Arizona but on a smaller scale. We really enjoyed the beautiful mountains.

places_url_reviews_title: Make sure you explore all the stops!
places_url_reviews_comment: I would recommend you take your time and visit as many of the stops as you can both on the north and south rim - the views of the canyon and waterfalls change during the day with the angle of the sun and the distance down the canyon. If you have the energy, take the steps down Uncle Toms, Grand View and the hike down to the upper falls - all worth the effort!
My third visit to this spectacular site and it is so breathtaking. One of our family's favorite spots in Yellowstone.
Super views of the canyon and the river far below. Highly recommended. The first parking lots were full but we parked in the last one and really enjoyed the walk back along the canyon rim.

places_url_reviews_title: A must-visit part of the Yellowstone experience
places_url_reviews_comment: The Yellowstone River falls, seen from Artist's Point or Uncle Tom's, is really a mandatory stop when you visit Yellowstone. The best time of day is morning, and the earlier you go, the better your chances of not getting stuck in a massive traffic jam. 8:30 seems to be about perfect, although the rainbow appears in the mist about an hour later in summer.

We had only a day & a half at the national park & wished we had 3 times the time to sample everything. The park gives you a 7-day pass for the price of admission, & just the 3 drives at this Grand Canyon will take you a day. Plan better next trip.

This is right up there with Old Faithful as a Must Do in Yellowstone. Make sure to hit all the view points. We really enjoyed the Red Rocks Lookout trail off of the Lookout Point stop along the North Rim. Don't miss the brink of the upper falls either.
Take the time to see. One of the sites well worth visiting. Traffic can be congested but people come and go creating parking spaces

It seems silly, but I'd never understood that Yellowstone got its name from the literal yellow stone of the canyon. A phenomenal site, and gorgeous. With the falls, it's quite a sight. Go to the brink of the Upper Falls: the power and pull of force is truly astounding.
The coloring of the strata here is really amazing. The river cuts deep. We must be looking at millions of years of history here. Plenty of excellent photos to be had at this site.

places_url_reviews_title: This Is So Deep and Steep
places_url_reviews_comment: You can see the sign posted on the main road to visit this section of the Loop. It is so deep and the sound of the water cascading down is loud and powerful. Check out the rock formations and you can guess on the age of this wonderful park. This just jumps out at you.

This was a surprise as although we had heard of the canyon we had no idea how spectacular this sight was. There are plenty of access points with good views, however, if you can get away from the crowds on one of the many trails you will be rewarded with truly fantastic views. We walked both the South Rim and the trail to Point Sublime and the views just got better and better. If you intend to visit the park you must include a visit to the Canyon. It is well worth stopping at Canyon Village and the Educational Centre where rangers can give you up to date info on the various trails. You will find their advice very helpful.

places_url_reviews_title: Easy hike hell of a virw
places_url_reviews_comment:
Beautiful
Absolutely breathtaking
Parts of this was shut down so we couldn't experience all of the falls but it was very pretty.

We visited Yellowstone 6/16-6/21. Everything was jammed packed with cars and bus-loads of tourists. Most of the park was un-visitable because of this, or when a parking lot wasn't full/closed, the trail or site was stuffed with throngs of people.
This was one of the first sites you come upon if you take the road that loops to the right when you come in. I would have stayed to see it even if there were thirty busses filled with tourists. It is striking and the best thing in the park, in my opinion, unless you get to go off the beaten path and stay (camp out) inside the park away from the crowds,

Yellowstone in itself was way to busy for me, so if I return it will be in the fall or spring. Too many rude tourists right now. This spot though is A must see, I suggest going at the crack of day break to avoid the mess of people that quickly ruins the beauty. The view points are great and a few great hikes off it too.
This is a must see in Yellowstone. The hike is short, but if you can't walk up hills or stairs, this is not for you. For everyone else a real treat.

We visited GC of Y during a late spring snowstorm and it was beyond beautiful. We had the rare chance to experience a day of winter in June and hike the upper rim. View the falls from Look Out Point, Red Rock Point, Artist's Point, & Brink, each offers a different point of view and adds to the experience. Late Spring offered a tremendous amount of water flow and with the snow, made for exquisite photos.
We were disappointed we could not go to Inspiration Point, or Uncle Tom's Trail. Artist's Point was our favorite and is an absolute must see.
Absolutely amazing. Worth the hike or the stairs to get to it. You will not want to miss this if you make the trip to Yellowstone.

This is a spectacular natural locale that is not to be missed. Does require some walking so be aware of that. Several very scenic views/walks. Some longer than others. The views are breathtaking, but some are very high up.
Best part of Yellowstone by far. Far exceeds expectations and other attractions like Old Faithful and Lamar Valley. See how Yellowstone got its name.

Gets very crowded so go early. Beautiful views. Limited parking and tour buses empty out making it crazy. We tried one afternoon but it was so crowded. Came by the next morning around 9:00 and it was almost empty.

This wonderful creation of nature can be seen from different points of the park, I suggest Artist Point for the Lower Yellowstone Falls and the canyon itself (here you have an amazing view), but another good place to see it (with Upper Yellowstone Falls) is Uncle Tom's Trail.

places_url_reviews_title: Gorgeous Grand Canyon of Yellowstone National Park
places_url_reviews_comment:
The Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone River and its waterfalls is an alluring and must-see attraction / tour of the Yellowstone National Park.
You can start from the Canyon Village's Canyon Visitor Education Center.
It is fascinating that Yellowstone NP also has its own 'Grand Canyon'.
As the first and very popular National Park established in USA since 1872, Yellowstone does get very crowded during summer time.
More than 4 million visitors admire and experience the Yellowstone National Park, annually.
Hot water acting on volcanic rock created the canyon's colors.
There is a few minutes walk to get to the view point which is well worth it for the magnificent views and sublime picture-taking.
Lookout Point has a vista of Lower Falls (308 feet) and walkways along the canyon's rims.
Grand view gives spectacular views of the canyon.
Helen Lim
Singapore

places_url_reviews_title: WOW words can not explain the beauty here!
places_url_reviews_comment: My family and I went here in July and it was so breath taking I can not wait to go back! The views were stunning, the water was the prettiest shade of blue I've ever seen! The hiking was wonderful!

Whether you walk it or drive it, you won't be disappointed! It is not a strenuous hike. Once you see all of the grand beauty that it has to offer, you will be glad that you even came to Yellowstone. This was one of the highlights of our trip. It was very beautiful and offered views like none other. Definitely stop and see.

places_url_reviews_title: Not quite GRAND but a very impressive sight
places_url_reviews_comment: We saw it from a number of vantage points each with a unique look easily accessible on the road without long hikes if you choose.
If here during busy season might be difficult to manage but we were here early. Some animals but they had not all came and there was still snow on ground and ice on lakes.
Well worth the trek to the end to see the falls, river and valley. This is the most iconic view seen in paintings and it's clear why when you see it.
We went in June and the water was raging. Falls and rivers were going crazy. This was a nice stop for a family photo.

We only went to the north side. Some lovely high view points and a number of trails below the rim. Some have quite steep switch back turns so be aware as coming back up to the top is much harder (obviously.). All well maintained and signposted. Very different in terms of colour and scale compared to the actual Grand Canyon but very manageable. As with the whole park remember binoculars.

places_url_reviews_title: Not sure why this is rated No. 1
places_url_reviews_comment: Don't get me wrong, the Yellowstone canyon is majestic and beautiful, but I don't think this is the best of Yellowstone. The view is nice, but comparable to Grand Canyon. There are falls, but smaller than Niagara. There are trails, but they do not beat those in Zion. I personally would spend more time watching wildlife and visiting geysors in Yellowstone.
The views are breathtaking. Falls are so beautiful. The walk way down to view the falls is so easy. Must see.
It was totally unexpected for us. The views blew us away. We drove from view point to view point on the north rim, but you could easily walk/hike it.
Spectacular, amazing, breathtaking, scary, and beautiful! Pics don't do it justice! You must see this when visiting Yellowstone.

To see the view of the falls and then look the other way and see the Grand Canyon of Yellowstone is a sight to see. It is endless and breathtaking. I was so amazed by the sights and could not get enough of it.

places_url_reviews_title: Spectacular Canyon - Check out the Pics
places_url_reviews_comment: Easily assessable with many vantage points the canyon is long and wide and provides another deep level to the diversity that is Yellowstone.

places_url_reviews_title: One of the most beautiful vistas in the park
places_url_reviews_comment: Yes it's packed with tourists, but the view is still worth it and you've GOT to get a photo of yourself with the falls in the background. Along the canyon rim there are lots of opportunities for short hikes as well.
The waterfalls are spectacularly beautiful. I thought they were the most magnificent site at Yellowstone.

OUTSTANDING, There are many pull outs, parking lots and trails. A lot of different ways you can enjoy the beautiful views of the Grand Canyon of Yellowstone. All get really crowded in the middle of the day. Brink of the Lower Falls and Upper Falls has many views that are easy and not so easy. Over looks and trails, you take you pick. They are all worth the walk.
The waterfall was amazing! Loved the scenic view! It was slightly raining when we visited and a beautiful rainbow shined across the waterfall. It was amazing!

There are several vantage points you can see the Canyon view from in the park and regardless of which you choose the view truly is stunning. Also each view gives you a different perspective so it's worth it to make the stop no matter how many times you have seen the Canyon.
Just beautiful, pictures do not truly show how big this is. Temps were mild in first of June but lots of people and lines to see things.

places_url_reviews_title: Beautiful views of the canyon, river & falls
places_url_reviews_comment:
This was one of the more crowded places we went. Arrived shortly after lunch. Nonetheless, it's still worth seeing even if crowded.
Drive the north & south rim roads. Walked to Inspiration Point & Artist Point. Views are absolutely gorgeous. There are plenty of great views if you're looking for short, easy walks from the parking lot.
There are also fairly short trails to get into the canyon & close to the falls. Those trails have some steep grade and/or lot of steps - somewhere around 120 one way. Uncle Tom's Trail was closed. If you're physically able, it's worth taking the trails.

places_url_reviews_title: A Breathtaking Canyon in the Heart of historic Yellowstone National Park
places_url_reviews_comment: This beautiful canyon, while not on the same scale as Arizona's Grand Canyon, is a wonder to behold. The canyon, which beautifully frames the Yellowstone River and lower falls can be viewed from above or below. From the upper rim there is a beautiful view of the falls and canyon below and if you're lucky you'll see an Osprey soaring overhead. For those who are able, a 10 minute descent down a winding, somewhat difficult paved trail affords gorgeous views of the canyon and falls close-up. The climb back up to the rim and parking areas is a good 25 minute walk requiring a moderate level of activity. Definitely wear hiking shoes or boots!
The Uncle Tom's Trail was closed for renovations, but we weren't sure for how long. If you cannot hike down Uncle Tom's Trail, then spend extra time at Artist point.

What can I say. Look at some pictures on line. These don't due the actual location justice. It's breathtaking. Very crowded. Hard to park-we came on a bus tour so this wasn't my concern.
A must if at Yellowstone.

places_url_reviews_title: South rim view from Artist Point
places_url_reviews_comment: We stayed in the Canyon Lodge and visited the Grand Canyon on the south rim at Artist Point two evenings after dinner. it's only about a five minute drive from Canyon. Spectacular views.

places_url_reviews_title: Since you can see from different places you see the magnificent Grand Canyon
places_url_reviews_comment: In some views you just must stop and contemplate what many thousand years have done to let us see this magnificent place. this is a must visit if you are in Yellowstone , and tried to see it from all of the different sites they have .
Nice waterfall. Alot of viewing points accessable (if you don't mind taking alot of stairs). Some nice birds nests for viewing

places_url_reviews_title: Gets its name for good reason.
places_url_reviews_comment: While completely different landscape you can quickly see why this place is named the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone. It's breathtaking. Worth the hikes to the lower Falls to view the Canyon.
Really looks like a smaller grand canyon. Very windy! There are several pull offs and it is worth hiking around a little at each one to get different aspects.
Recommended by friends not to miss. Beautiful waterfalls! The colors in the rock were magnificent! Truly worth seeing.

places_url_reviews_title: Beautiful views with a short walk
places_url_reviews_comment: Park in the lot at the end of the South Rim road and it's a short walk to one of the most beautiful sights in the park. The beautiful canyon with the waterfall is breathtaking, a perfect site for a photo op and taking in the scenery of the canyon. I wouldn't miss this stop if you're at Yellowstone.

places_url_reviews_title: Must SEE in your travels around Yellowstone
places_url_reviews_comment: This is fantastic. We stopped at one of the overlooks. A short walk down and you have a gorgeous view of the falls, canyon and an ospreys nest. I also recommend getting an app called Just Ahead... this app gives you a tour and told us about so many sights and information we would never have known about! It was excellent!
Very pretty, some of my favorite vacation photos came from this spot, especially Calcite Springs Overlook.

We drove both the north and south canyon viewing roads and found parkin on the South Canyon view to be very congested. The views of the canyon, Osprey nests and other birds were great. The trails had some snow remaining and required caution. Restroom facilites are available if inadequate for the number of visitors.

places_url_reviews_title: What can you say that hasn't already been said
places_url_reviews_comment: Simply a fantastic place to visit & one that will stay with you for a very long time. Throughout the area the scenery is lovely& the wildlife everywhere, bears, moose, wolves etc.

We went in mid-May when some of the roads were still closed due to snow - so we were only able to visit the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone from the North Rim but it's still so breathtaking.
You can see all the colors throughout the canyon, the powerful river below (with steam in some places), and the Lower Falls which super powerful, even when you don't get to walk up close.
There was an osprey nest on one of the rock spires that looked huge and you could see two osprey chilling. I've read they keep reusing the same nest for years, so I can imagine how long it took to build up to that size.
When we went there was mild snow falling, and there was a rainbow across the Lower Falls. Definitely worth a stop at each of the viewpoints.
Logistically, we entered from the town of Canyon to the North Rim one way road. There are several places along the road to stop and walk a short distance to an overlook or vista - or you can park and walk along the North Rim Trail, which walks along them, too.

The waterfall is wonderful. I would recommend driving the North Rim - less people. Take the short strenuous Red Rock trail from the North Rim to get a closer view.
Unfortunately the road to Inspiration Point was closed in beginning of June 2017.

Great view of the lower falls. The power of the river seems awesome.
The south rim viewing area was great with plenty of shade & room to move around. The outhouses were pretty dirty though.
We also stopped @ the north rim and that view is great too but parking is trickier.
Both rims have trails to get REAL close but we didn't go down because of the hike it would have been with the 1 & 2 year olds.
When you are driving on the grand loop this is one of the attractions you must see. Its a beautiful canyon and you can see the biggest fall from this point.

Part of the trail was still snow covered when we visited in late May, it was still worth the hike. The views were gorgeous. There are a lot of places to stop and get amazing pictures. The canyon is other worldly. To think just a small river created all that. The geological history you can see is also amazing. Go in May and go early to avoid crowds. It was not crowded at this stop and the paths were moderate. Don't wear flip flops.
The views are unforgettable. One could stand here for hours and just admire the beauty of nature. Put this on your to see list.
Make sure and hike the Brink of the Upper and Lower Falls on the North Rim.. and then visit Artists Point on the South Rim...

places_url_reviews_title: Very colorful canyons and raging rivers
places_url_reviews_comment: Amazing the varied topography of yellowstone and the geologic forces that created the beautiful scenery. We came in late May, the perfect time, after the melt, and ahead of the summer crowds.
This was out of our way about a half hour but definitely worth seeing. It is just beautiful with the long waterfall coming down the canyon. I definitely recommend seeing this.

When getting in the parking lot, I was a little put off by how many tour buses were there and how many people were seen but it was totally worth it.
The views are amazing, the waterfalls are breathtaking. Its crowded but once you get to your spot along with the view, it's all worth it.

Love the sound of a waterfall, the power. I would have rated it a 5 but the access to the falls themselves, Uncle Toms Cabin & the stairway down was closed, Maybe next time. Great photo op. Close your eyes for 30 seconds and just listen.
Can't believe the beauty of this place! The canyon is amazing. And the drive is thrilling! Take a hike to the falls! It's worth the effort if you are in good health!
Not everyone knows that Yellowstone has its own grand canyon--and it's magnificent! One of the most amazing natural scenes I've ever visited.
Beautiful beyond belief. Pull overs on the road have beautiful views of the canyon. A definite must see while in Yellowstone.
Yellowstone has some outstanding scenery but probably the best is the Grand Canyon. Splendid cliffs and white water river. Quite easily viewed particularly from the North Rim drive.

We did take the 300+ steps down to Uncle Toms. It was worth it. Is it scary climbing metal stairs bolted to the side of a cliff, for me yes. My husband is usually wary of heights but he was fine. Much better view if you can handle the stairs. I'm 57 and did have to take a few breather stops. Go for it, you'll be glad you did.
The walk down is fine if you have no fear of heights. The walk backup the switchbacks is strenuous if you have any conditions. Take your time and you should be fine.

There are many different viewpoints. Visit them all because you can see the falls from many angles, but also different views of the canyon. Hiking along the south rim gives the most interesting view and it's just a nice hike
Very different than the rest of the park, great view of the falls and gorge from the overlooks. Keep children close, the trails are safe but the overlooks are perched on the edge of the canyon walls.

Recently visited Yellowstone and the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone - spectacular views along the rim drive. Great canyon views at the several overlooks along the drive. Great colors in the canyon and spectacular views of the river below.
This is one of my favorite spots and worth taking the time. Currently there are some closures around it but you can still get to most of the picture perfect spots.

So much fun, hiking spots, and breathtaking views. Love the river! Such a pretty place to hike the trails. Two of the trails (Uncle Tom's and another one that led to a good view of the fall) had snow on it. Sketchy! We tried hiking Uncle Tom's trail, but the snow was just too much. And it was muddy. But still, cool to say we hiked in the snow.
Was very crowded, but worth it. Beautiful falls and deep chasms. Some walking, but not difficult with only a few steps to go up or down.
Amazing landscapes! Try watching the birds and waterfall instead of taking selfies they are grand. Also stay on the trails and hold onto your hats in windy days!

Probably the prettiest thing we saw in the park. The view is amazing. Our guide suggested we avert our eyes from looking at the canyon until we could see it full on to augment the impact, and he was right! The first glimpse is breathtaking. We even saw an asprey nest! Save some time and make your way to this. A trip to the park is not complete without it.

Most people come to Yellowstone to see Old Faithful and the bears and bison, but the Yellowstone Grand Canyon is definitely worth a visit. The river has carved a very deep gorge with two large waterfalls and numerous rapids. There are a number of trails and vantage points.
The sun off the rocks was incredible the canyon is deep. If you want a good view if lower falls uncle Tom's steps good going down takes your oxygen away come back up at 380 steps

Part of the road was still closed for snow/ice. It's a record snow year in the park so the melt right now really creates some wonderful waterfalls.
Restrooms had long lines & parking limited in some stopping areas. Also, a lot of trails in both Yellowstone & Tetons are still too snowy or muddy to safely hike.
Plan with caution & always be open to "plan B".
The lower falls are lovely. I was here in spring so the amount of water flowing was amazing. Birds soaring and bright colors on the canyon.

This was one of the most incredible views we had ever seen. Specifically, we went to the Artist Point stop in the south rim of the canyon. There is some hiking available there, but we just enjoyed the views, which are really awe inspiring.
We only got to see a bit of the area due to snow and road closures, but well worth the time and effort.
Be sure to check out the waterfalls. They are great in the spring with the spring run off from the snow.
We walked to the viewpoint and part of the trail and loved the views. We were also lucky enough to see a soaring osprey.

Yes, there will be tons of other tourists there taking pictures, but relax and enjoy the global camerade of sharing this truly magnificent sight. With patience, this is an easy place to get epic photos.
An iconic American landscape that should not be missed. Beautiful in every direction. You need to keep an eye on your kids because even though there are walls, they are easily climbable!
Absolutely must see. Section of the park was closed so couldnt see up close. That was a shame. Maybe next time.

places_url_reviews_title: One of many beautiful places in Yellowstone
places_url_reviews_comment: There are more beautiful locations in Yellowstone than any website can cover. Check out several locations / angles. The Canyon and falls look different from each.
All you have heard is true. Unbelievable view. Color tells you why it's called Yellowstone. Must see. Come early in the year to avoid lines. Will not be disappointed.
Gorgeous views of the canyon, river and striking water fall images! Walk the trail that follows the river canyon to see a new sliver of beauty at every turn!
Beautiful part of the park... must do in Yellowstone. If you are going in May, be careful with the snow and ice on the trail as they were not cleared.

places_url_reviews_title: Almost as good as Washington state
places_url_reviews_comment: Really nice but not up to Lamar Valley and we preferred Lamar Valley. Gorgeous scenery but not many animals
So perfect! So beautiful. Wish we would have had more time to see more things. But this place and the waterfalls were so beautiful!
Not as big as the Grand Canyon but equally if not more interesting regarding the forces at play that formed it. Great colors and multiple viewpoints to enjoy the spectacle.

This is a must see!!! Very beautiful location. I had my two little blonde blue eyed babies with me and I was swarmed by Asian tourists snapping pictures of them. It was crazy! Back to the point...this place is beautiful! Don't miss it!!
Over the views! My wife has some trouble hiking but this was not a problem. A short walk and we were at the lower falls! The road was still closed to the upper falls.

places_url_reviews_title: A must do for all visitors!
places_url_reviews_comment: Beautiful location! Try to go early in the morning or late in the evening to avoid crowds. Take your camera!

This location is a must stop in a visit to Yellowstone. It is colorful, dynamic, unique and bursting with energy from it's water flow and falls. The canyon is dizzyingly steep and deep. The vistas are well placed and could keep you looking all day.

Stayed at West Yellowstone for 5 days, entered the park by 8am most mornings.
Our first day was a nature overload, we saw bison, elk, a bear, a coyote.
Car parks were mostly quiet, although the coaches did turn up from time to time but we just moved on to quieter areas.
Route from Norris to Mammoth has roadworks so a bit of a hold up there.
Wonderful falls and geysers, we will return.
Awesome place ...very scenic...however most hiking trails were closed during the month of May. Wud suggest covering the sightseeing locations both in the north rim and the South rim.
This is the first time we have been here this early. The snow was so beautiful. There seemed to be a lot tourist here for the first part of May. We didn't have any trouble finding a parking place.

The Grand Canyon of Yellowstone is a must see item in your Yellowstone trip.
There are 4 view points to enjoy the magnificent site. 2 of the points are on the rim and are accessible for strollers and where chairs. Other two view points take you closer to the water falls but they need effort as you will walk down around almost 200 feet below the rim level. You can hear the roar of the waterfalls and there is a good view of the falls itself.
It will take almost one full day to enjoy the beauty from all view points. The best time of the year is June-July or Oct-Nov time frame when the temperature above 50-60 degrees.
Please make sure you are wearing sneakers/sport shoes to go the lower view points.

places_url_reviews_title: Amazing colors and views. A must see.
places_url_reviews_comment: The canyon has amazing color variations in the yellow/orange/sienna palette. We did a couple of short hikes on both side and took in all of the falls in addition to the canyon itself. Allow for three hours to enjoy it all.

If you have even wondered how Yellowstone got its name then look no further than the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone. Looking down into the Canyon is breathtaking as well as the views up and down the canyon.

The Falls area is one of the most beautiful areas of this park. Stunning scenery with tremendous falls and unique beautiful soil in the canyon...has got to be one of the most gorgeous places on earth. Lots of trails and varied overlooks....plan on several hours here to take it all in.
The name is very appropriate. "Grand Canyon of The Yellowstone". Scenery is breathtaking. Watching the water is mesmerizing. The power of the water is humbling.

We went on a lot of ranger led hikes as well as private hikes with Yellowstone Association Institute here. There are strong winds here. We had to really hold onto our little kid here. Absolutely beautiful and must see. But then again, what part of Yellowstone isn't beautiful and must see. Be careful of the trails. We saw a lot of young twenty year olds taking selfies and self videos as they walked the trails without paying attention to where they were going. Please take time to take in your surroundings- it is absolutely more magnificent then a selfie.
One of the many wonderful places of the park and if you are there then you should visit and enjoy the view.
One of americas most beatyfull spots!! Take the walk out to the point about-a Half mile walk for best View of the falls.

Are you looking for inspiration? Do you need to see God's glory in His creation? Do you need to be near the natural art left behind by the forces of nature? Look no further. The Grand Canyon of Yellowstone is a natural wonder that changes lives every day. It is that special.
It is not to be missed during a visit to Yellowstone; especially if it is a once in a lifetime visit for you. Take your time. There are some great hikes at this canyon one might miss, if not made aware. Uncle Tom's Trail will get you a great vantage point of the Lower Falls. Red Rock Point is a trail accessed from Lookout Point. You can get a more direct, straight on view of the Falls from Red Rock Point. It's worth the hike. Both hikes are not too long. But both are steep.
Uncle Tom's Trail has an abundance of steps to conquer. Red Rock trail is steep, but no steps. Have fun!

places_url_reviews_title: One of the best views in park
places_url_reviews_comment: This really is one of the prettiest sights in Yellowstone. Many people miss this area on a quick drive through the park. I would skip Old Faithful before missing this stop. You will be amazed with the beauty.
Amazing views!!! Yellowstone is just fantastic and unique. Loved everything in this National Park. A must for National Park lovers.

places_url_reviews_title: Makes you feel the size of an ant.
places_url_reviews_comment: There are many spots to stop and see the canyon. All of them make you feel small next the huge canyon cut down by the Yellowstone River. If you plan on hiking any of the trails, make sure to take along bug spray. With all that water, it is easy to run across a lot of mosquitos.
Very beautiful view and amazing landscape. Wildlife and nature is impressing. You should pass same days to visit all this park.
What more needs to be said. The water of the Yellowstone River cuts through the rocks falling many feet. The vantage point is increible! v

places_url_reviews_title: Snow Coach Tour is a Must!
places_url_reviews_comment: We had a wonderul Xanterra guide that was very funny and witty. He seemed knowledgeable about the area. We a great experience everywhere we stopped and explored. The frozen and half frozen waterfalls were breathtaking. The view of the Tetons from Yellowstone Canyon was amazing! Winter in Yellowstone is a once in a lifetime bucket list absolute must!

In addition to famous and wondrous geothermal features, Yellowstone is also well known for its spectacular canyons and waterfalls. When you visit Grand Canyon of Yellowstone, you can enjoyed not only the beautiful colors of the canyon and its magnificent height but also marvelous sights of the Lower, Upper, and Crystal Falls.
There are numerous views of the Falls and Grand Canyon from both the north and south sides of the Grand Canyon, most of which require only a short walk or virtually no walk to see. However, this is one of the most famous spots at the park so during the peak times of the day, it may be hard to find a parking space. It's always wiser to start the day early for the most famous areas of the park or visit them later in the day.
- From the north side of the canyon: Using the North Rim Drive, you can stop and view the Lower Falls and Grand Canyon of Yellowstone at Inspiration Point, Grand View Point, and Lookout Point. On this side, you can also journey to the top of the falls and feel its extreme power, commanding respect, and intense roar as it drops into the rainbow of mist beneath by hiking down the Brink of the Lower Falls Trail. This is a short 3/4 mile hike but intense with great drop in elevation and a lot of switch backs.
- From the south side of canyon: Using the South Rim Drive, you can stop and view the Lower Falls and Grand Canyon of Yellowstone at Artists Point. Artists Point is where you can have the most beautiful grand view of the Lower Falls together with Grand Canyon of Yellowstone and the snaking Yellowstone River below. On this side, you can also journey down the Uncle Tom's Trail to have a close-up face off with the electrifying Lower Falls.

There are areas of Yellowstone that are not to be missed and this is definitely one of those! If possible opt for ranger guided walks/talks as the knowledge they share with visitors makes for a more complete park experience!

This is by far the best thing in the park for a reason. Perfect for nature-lovers, national park aficionados, photographers, artists, writers, sightseers, basic tourists, and those who have seen it all. Every perspective is a masterpiece to inspire an artist and to awe any viewer. No wait is needed to see this like Old Faithful, no large crowds at one spot like other geysers, and no need to move around to feel like you have fully experienced it as this canyon feels like every single location is a new experience. The falls, the river, the hikes (both the strenuous and easy ones), and everything in between were some of the best experiences of my life. Even the large stairway to get to the falls isn't enough to hinder my opinion on this wonder of the world.
take the time and go, you won't be disappointed..as a photographer it was just something beautiful to see

places_url_reviews_title: Amazing! Be prepared to climb stairs!
places_url_reviews_comment: This place is one of the highlights of the park! The waterfall is amazing and there are different places you can climb down to see it from different angles!. The trails are safe, but they are not recommended to people with knee or back problems (you need to climb a lot of stairs), however, there are accesible places to look at the Canyon from the top.

places_url_reviews_title: One of the high-points of the park
places_url_reviews_comment:
Gorgeous views from many different perspectives. Should not be missed during any season in the park.
Can be extremely busy during the peak season

We hiked the north and south rim trails with a 2 year old. He was able to walk good portions of it and we wore him on our backs the rest of the way. Some parts are more strenuous than others so I think you can plan to do portions according to your abilities.

places_url_reviews_title: This is one of my favorite spots in the park.
places_url_reviews_comment:
There is a view point with benches and we just sit there and look and listen.
Near sunset is especially spectacular.
There are vintage and vintage copies of photos and postcards of this spot.
This is my happy place.
When I'm stressed, I just remember my last visit. :)
There are some stairs but not like some parts of the park which are up and up and up and down and down and down and can be slippery.
(June 2015 and two visits before.)
One of the highlights of Yellowstone. Our favorite time to visit was at twilight as the setting sun made the river look like molten, flowing, gold.

I stopped first at the Brink of the Lower Falls, the initial stop on the one-way, mile-long North Rim Drive located just south of Canyon Village.
There's 10 switchbacks on the trail that bring you down 800 feet in altitude to reach the top of the lower falls and the magnificent views of the canyon. Don't think about the hike back up. Just know that the views at the bottom are so worth it.
This is one of the highlights of Yellowstone, yet one that can be easily missed by those who don't realize how spectacular the Yellowstone River canyon is.

This is more of a review of the park as a whole and covers a variety of sights. Be prepared for a long wait to get into the park if you are visiting in the busy months of July / August. I think we were lined up outside of the park for about 30 mins just trying to get in. This was in the South Entrance. We first went to the West Thumb area where we saw 6 female elks lazing in the grass. There is a walk here which is about 800 meters around the various types of Geysers. Also stop at the Volcano Mud Pools which is pretty interesting. Here we got up close with some Bison that were sunbathing on the path. Then stopped at the Lower and Upper Falls. Not far from here is the "Grand Canyon of Yellowstone" which is a large canyon filled with beautiful reds, oranges and browns in colour. Head to Norris Geyser Basin which is a 1.6km round trip with lots of colourful Geysers to look at. Gibbon Falls is a great waterfall if you just want a good view from the parking lot. The Middle Geyser Basin is home to the famous Grand Prismatic Geyser - this is the colourful one always used in the brochures. It is extremely impressive but if the weather is bad or windy you won't see too much. We had a lot of steam and wind and really couldn't see too much. We had to wait for a break in the wind before we saw the colours.
One thing to note is that the parking in the park in summer is ridiculous. There are not enough car park spaces for the large amount of tourists especially in summer so you will end up parked on the side of the road and walk in. Be mindful do not park in spaces that say no parking. We did see people checking parked cars and writing out tickets.
Overall the park is just amazing. It is mostly all about wildlife and geysers so if you like them then you will have a blast. Try and go in either May or late August early September to avoid the traffic madness.

Had never heard of the Grand Canyon of Yellowstone before this trip, but we were very impressed. The different colors and layers of the walls look like a child's kaleidoscope, changing as the sun moves.
Even in the cold/wind/fog and rain this is a spectacular canyon. Snow coach ride there was quite fun. Viewed the canyon from both sides and various points.

We loved hiking in the Grand Canyon of Yellowstone! We hiked both the Lower Falls Brink Trail (3/8 mi. and 600 foot drop) and the Uncle Tom's Trail (328 steps down in the canyon for a beautiful view of the Lower Falls), and although both trails were steep, they were both worth it! We also stayed at the new Canyon Hotel, and everything was brand new and lovely. We walked over to the cafeteria for breakfast, which was nice because it was quick, cheap, and had good options. We liked staying in the Canyon Area because of it's central location ... we would stay here again. We liked that it was less crowded than either the Old Faithful or Mammoth areas, and yet we could easily drive to both locations.

places_url_reviews_title: The best views are had early morning when the crowds are still waking-up.
places_url_reviews_comment:
Busses crowd into the parking lots all year round.
Go after Labor Day and get up early to beat them to the best spots.
Don't be afraid to pull off the road into one of the hundreds of spaces to enjoy your little piece of Yellowstone to yourself.
The stairs might get you on the way back up, but it is an absolute must. Really remarkable and great for young kids. We cannot wait to go again.

places_url_reviews_title: In the winter it is a whole different park
places_url_reviews_comment: This is a great place to stop off at, and take some time to look around, remember don't just take pictures try videos too with sound

Such a beautiful and magnificent place. They have some steps to go down and get best view but are pretty steep and before you even start the trail to descend it warns you of who shouldn't attempt it. I didn't do it as I'm affraid of heights and wasn't in good physical shape but my daughter and husband went down and they loved it. They did say it was slippery at times.

Yellowstone National Park holds beautiful and untouched land of the United States. My family and friends took part in the Yellowstone Lower Loop full day tour, stopping at many attractions. On the tour, we went to Grand Canyon of Yellowstone, Grand Prismatic Spring, and Firehole Canyon. Yellowstone opened my eyes to how beautiful the natural world is.
One of the places we went was the Grand Canyon of Yellowstone. The tour bus stopped at the entrance, so we could hike to the canyon. Our tour guide informed us about the area of Yellowstone and the wildlife it contained. On the journey to the canyon, I saw lots of wildlife I hadn’t seen before. The wild animals were ginormous and fascinating. The canyon was astonishing. Canyons and mountains surrounded a giant waterfall and a blue river. Looking around, I saw the most beautiful picture of the earth and wildlife engulfing me. Until I went to the Grand Canyon of Yellowstone, I never realized how big the world was compared to the small town I live in.
In Yellowstone, the tour took us to the Grand Prismatic Spring. The hike to the spring was enjoyable because there were small hot springs all around that you could look into. It was important to stay on the path so we didn’t disturb wildlife or accidentally step in a boiling spring. After being amazed by the hot springs on the way, my mind was blown when I finally reached Grand Prismatic. In order to get a view of the entire spring, we had to climb a hill that looks onto it. The vibrant colors of Grand Prismatic make it a must see. Blue, red, orange, and pink filled the steaming water below us. Grand Prismatic is the most fascinating sight I have ever seen. I had no idea the world contained such breathtaking features.
The excursion to Firehole Canyon was my favorite adventure during the Yellowstone tour. Firehole Canyon is a beautiful canyon connected to the Firehole River. Part of the canyon consisted of still, warm water that we got to relax in. The water was the perfect temperature for swimming because the river is connected to various hot springs in Yellowstone. It was very peaceful relaxing on the rocks in the water and looking around at the beautiful cliffs and mountains surrounding me. Firehole Canyon also has an area with cliffs and rapids. It was exhilarating to jump off of the cliffs and into the rapids. My friends and I spent hours flinging ourselves into the fast-moving rapids. We had a lot of fun at Firehole Canyon, while still enjoying beautiful scenery.
Yellowstone National Park opened my eyes to a world outside of the city. I recommend going on the Yellowstone tour to enjoy beautiful scenery and wildlife. The tour provided lots of information and fun as we traveled through the park. Taking part in the Yellowstone tour allowed to me to experience and see sights that were once unknown to me.

places_url_reviews_title: OK not the Grand Canyon, but pretty cool
places_url_reviews_comment: This is a beautiful geological feature. There are several access points and all are worth a visit. The Yellowstone River has cut this 20 mile canyon with 3 outstanding water falls, the Lower Fall being the highest.
Once in a lifetime experience in the winter. Spectacular view of the canyon with ice formations everywhere.

This was sort of a bonus for us. We were expecting geysers, pools, bison, mountains, etc. I didn't realize how significant this is. It is a beautiful canyon with a very dramatic waterfall. There are multiple look out points which I recommend trying for the variety of views. There is also a hike to the bottom that we didn't get a chance to try, but I hear is worth it. Try visiting at different times of the day, the colors vary significantly.

Snow blankets the canyon, but Clark's Nutcrackers happily sings their song. The waterfall is partially frozen. A big "snowball" is formed in front of the falls as water spray from the waterfall freezes. Beautiful. Grateful to behold such a vision. Fabulous view.

places_url_reviews_title: Can't Miss....Fantastic, more than words can express
places_url_reviews_comment: it is worth the short walk to get a full view. Be sure to bring your camera and just stay a while and just listen, look and meditate on this great beauty, God's creation.

My fiance and I were a little shocked by the colder weather during October this past year but we didn't let that stop us from adventuring down to the scenic spot to see the breathtaking site. Not only could we feel the cool water spraying our face, the sun reflecting on the water making it look like 100 colors, but most importantly we saw how truly beautiful nature can be when its properly preserved. Even though we didn't plan on it being as chilly as it was i would still visit during this time because we almost had the park to ourselves!

This is one of the best things I have ever seen. This view is absolutely stunning. I did the walk down to the lower view of the waterfall. I am not sure this was necessary. It is quite a trek back up. This is a must see!

It's harder than you think doing the littel switchbacks to get to the falls. I lived at high elevations (4400 ft. ) at the the time and still had to take a few rests. Was it worth it? Absolutely. Take a few breathers on the way back up, you'll be glad you did.
The view was spectacular. we took the little hike down to the scenic spot. I remember seeing a rainbow. You have to see it to believe it.
Awesome waterfall(Lower falls). Uncle Tom’s Trail is totally worth it.The trial goes from the top of the canyon to the base of lower falls.

places_url_reviews_title: An amazing spot in an amazing park
places_url_reviews_comment: The mostly frozen waterfall is always a treat. We skied into a spot and hiked down a trail to get full frontal views. Not a hard hike.

Incredible views of this spectacular nature gift.
Visited on September and was supposed to be "low" season, we had to drive a bit to get a spot.
Easy walks to viewpoints.
One of the most beautiful waterfalls you could ever see. You don't want to miss seeing the Grand Canyon of Yellowstone on your visit to Yellowstone. It is absolutely beautiful.

We have been misled by other sites that call themselves
the 'Grand Canyon of the ---' before, but this stop actually lived up to it name, somewhat. It's not the Grand Canyon, but it's a deep sliver of a canyon with an impressive falls and a river cutting through it that is worth the short hike to view it.
This is really spectacular. The canyon really beautiful. Wonderful for nature shots and getting pictures taken with a loved one. One of the must sees in the park.
It's been years since I've been, but this place is unbelievable. The views are breathtaking and just being in the middle of one of the most famous National Parks is just amazing.

This has to be one of the most beautiful places in Yellowstone national park. There is a medium level hike before you reach to the view point both from North and South rim. Really a treat for the eyes

places_url_reviews_title: Great Views, but crowded look out
places_url_reviews_comment: I've stopped here on both of my trips to Yellowstone. It is worth a visit, however tour buses are also always dropping people off so there are always large crowds.
We loved Yellowstone, but this isn't the most spectacular canyon our country has to offer. It is still amazing and beautiful and a Yellowstone icon that you cannot miss.
No matter where you view from, North Rim, South Rim its Spectacular! The yellow canyon walls gave Yellowstone it's name. Upper falls, Lower Falls visit them all, you will be impressed.

This should be the top hike of Yellowstone. There are beautiful sites after every turn and it is well marked. After you hike about 1/2 mile or less, you will leave behind the point-and-shoot crowd and have the entire path to yourself. Our six and eight year old grandkids had not trouble with this.

Whoever said that the us does not have natural tourist spots has not visited this place!
Even for seasoned travelers, this place is a must-see! Words would not be enough to capture the beauty of this place!
It is a great place for family or friends!
Beautiful views, definitely take your camera. It can get crowded so earlier is better to visit, parking is limited.

Breathtaking and a must see if you are going to visit Yellowstone. We took our time and sat quietly to take in the beauty of the scene. We went in August and didn't feel like there were too many people around, some crowds but manageable.

places_url_reviews_title: Truly is the Grand Canyon of Yellowstone
places_url_reviews_comment: I went here when half the park was closed due to snow. It's a stunning waterfall and the views from all lookouts are amazing! The hike down the the brink is not long but does have elevation change. I would spend at least an hour or two here to see the falls from different views and spend time hiking around!

When I heard of Grand Canyon, I only thought of the one, you know, the GRAND CANYON in Arizona. I didn't know there was one in Yellowstone. When I reached around 4pm. Damn, was I delightfully surprised. You could hear the roar of the tall waterfall. I think there was a path to go near it, but I didn't go down. I stayed on the safer and higher side of the canyon.
The path were well-paved, it ain't muddy nor rocky, quite feet-friendly, most of the path were wheelchair friendly too. Looking across the canyon was nothing very spectacular. The best part was looking down into the canyon. The sunlight, on that day, was bright and brought out the contrast of the rugged surface of the cliffs. The colours of the canyon walls and the blue water of the river was beautiful without photoshop.
I believe the trek can go on and on and on, I didn't venture too far. I do see there are people across the canyon on the other side. So, you probably could spend a good half a day if you are into photography. If not, just 40min - 1hr is a pretty comfortable time.
Oh, we got a bonus to see a hawk chasing off a raven which flew too near to its nest.

Tremendous view over the canyon towards the falls. Nice hiking in the area. We went in early October 2016 and it wasn't crowded at a. The weather was perfect and the early afternoon sun was lovely for photos.
I haven't been to the Grand Canyon, but I am amazed that it is more grand than this. It is so neat to look at the layers in the canyon walls.
Superb and amazing. Best outside the highly touristy season (avoid the summer). Use the maps provided to find the best spots.
Can't describe the scenery and how beautiful it is. Make sure you get out of your car and take it all in. Many hikes in the surrounding area. All worth it
You must stop here. The views of the canyons are spectacular. I would say they rival the Grand Canyon in AZ.

This is a must-see. There are several trails to take, some easier than others. We took the Lower Falls trail (was with my two children, 10 & 12), and that was a good distance and difficulty, basically straight down and back up. Beautiful view of the falls, river above and beyond, and canyon. We were even treated with a rainbow!

We enjoyed absolutely everything in Yellowstone and this was one of the highlights. The view from the top is spectacular. Unfortunately, due to time constraints, we were unable to hike to the bottom but we spoke to a lovely couple who said it was well worth it. I can't say enough good things about Yellowstone. I think everyone should visit, we certainly plan to do so many more times!
